dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quadrangle of Army buildings is quiet and deserted. A broken-down taxi drives in at one corner and slowly makes way around the quadrangle. SUPERIMPOSED over shot is the legend:

dialogues.speaker: PEARL HARBOR
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up across the street from camera. A soldie gets out, pulls two heavily loaded barracks bags after hi He pays the driver, hoists the bags to his back, moves to camera. The taxi drives away slowly. The soldier walks to steps leading to a low building. He is PREWITT (called "P for short), 22 years old, well-built, good-looking. He we an enlisted man's uniform and on the sleeves are marks wh chevrons have been removed. He pauses, looks up over the door. CAMERA PANS UP to sign which reads: ORDERLY ROOM - COMPANY, 219TH REGIMENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small thin soldier in an undershirt and fatigue pants b out of the screen door and into shot. He is wielding a fr broom. This is PRIVATE ANGELO MAGGIO. He is violent and f and sour and friendly. He sees Prewitt's legs but not his face, speaks as he sweeps a cloud of dust off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGID
dialogues.text: Fine way to pass the time. Good for the mind.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Hello, Maggio. Maggio turns and stares at Prew, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Prew...?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (nods) I transferred out of Fort Shatter. Maggio notices the marks on the sleeves where the stripes have been removed. Prew follows his glance.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: You quit the Bugle Corps...?  Prew nods. Maggio jerks his head toward the sign.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: To here...?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (shrugs) That's what the orders say.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: You made a bad mistake. This outfit they can give back to Custer. Prew smiles slightly, starts toward door.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: The Captain ain't in yet. Prew puts down his barracks bags.

dialogues.speaker: PREY
dialogues.text: I'll look around.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (smiles for first time) Maybe we borrow some money from a twenty per cent man and take a real trip to town some night.

dialogues.speaker: PHEW
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew walks slowly down the raised porch alongside the str He takes the mouthpiece of a bugle from his pocket, jiggl it idly, a habit of his. He comes to the Dayroom, glances through the screen door, goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dayroom has a pool table, ping-pong table, a radio, e Moth-eaten, upholstered chairs line both walls. The place empty as Prew enters. He looks around casually, sees the table in an alcove. He moves over to it, puts the bugle mouthpiece in his pocket, picks a cue from the rack on th wall. He switches on the light, chalks the cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The triangle of balls is already racked on the table. Pre addresses the cue ball, shoots and breaks the rack solidl He watches the balls hurry around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’re you think you're doing!? Why ain't you out in the field with the Compny? What’s your name? The voice is brawling, brash, vigorous. Prew turns slowly CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to INCLUDE FIRST SERGEANT MILTON WARD almost at Prew's elbow. He is thirty-four, big and powerf has a neatly-trimmed moustache.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Prewitt. Transfer from Shafter.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I heard about you.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I heard about you, too, Warden.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Well, put up that cue and come along. This here's a rifle outfit, Prewitt. You ain't suppose to enjoy yourself before sundown. The Man's very particlar about little things like that. Warden goes out of the Dayroom. Prew puts up the cue and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden walk along the porch, Warden a few pac ahead. They go into the Orderly Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden enter. Maggio is sweeping the room. MAZZIOLI, a bespectacled, intellectual-looking Private Fi Class, is at the clerk's desk, opening it, taking out pap etc. Prew sits on a bench as Warden goes over to Mazzioli

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Mazzioli! Grant went to the hospital yesterday. Did you make up his sick record? Did you make a note for the morning report?! You're the Compny Clerk. The lousy Sickbook is your job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those medics didn't get the Sickbook back till late yesterday -- I'll tend to it right now --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. I already done it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio has swept his way over to Prew. He stops sweeping stares at the other man as if still incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: But you the beat bugler they got over at Shatter. You probly the best on this whole Rock. In b.g., Warden has turned from Mazzioli and is looking a Prew. Prew looks back coolly, answers Maggio thoughtfully

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That's true. Maggio wags his head, bends over to pick up wastepaper basket.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Well, friend, I feel for you. But from my position I can't quite reach you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Ten-sh-HUT! Prewitt, Mazzioli and Maggio spring to attention. The scr door bangs and CAPTAIN DANA HOLMES enters shot. He wears cavalry boots and spurs. He is about forty, unsure of himself, therefore always too certain with his men. He no pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: At ease. Good morning, men. Anything special this morning Sergeant Warden? I've only a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: New man here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Bring him in. Holmes goes into his office. Warden jerks his thumb towa the door. Prewitt goes into the office. Warden follows hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is seated at his desk as Prewitt and Warden enter. placard on it reads: CAPTAIN HOLMES. A smaller desk nearb has a placard' reading: 1ST SERGEANT WARDEN. Warden seats himself at this desk. On the walls are framed photographs prizefighters as well as one of a large golden trophy. On Holmes' desk is a small framed photograph of a very attractive blonde woman. Prewitt comes to attention in fr of Holmes' desk.

dialogues.speaker: PREWITT
dialogues.text: Sir, Private Robert E. Lee Prewitt reporting to the Compny Commander as ordered.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: At ease. (takes papers out of drawer, glances through them) They sent your service record over... Twenty-two years of age... born in Kentucky... enlisted first at Fort Myer, Virginia... Bugle Corps... re-enlisted for overseas duty... Fort Shafter... First Bugler... (benignly) Prewitt, I always make it a policy to talk to my new men. It's important for an officer and his men to understand each other. Now I have a fine smooth-running outfit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes cannot see Warden who is grinning at Prewitt with unholy glee.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Plenty of room for advancement for a man who knows how to soldier. But he's got to show me he's got it on the ball. I don't know what you've been used to in the Bugle Corps, but in my outfit we run it by the book. What kind of trouble were you in over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What made you transfer out, then?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It's a personal matter, air

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh. I see... He studies Prew for a moment, sees Warden on the edge of chair, watching hawk-like.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Something you wanted to ask Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (explodes suddenly) Who? Me? Whv, yes, air. You had Corpral's stripes in the Bugle Corps, Prewitt. You took a bust to buck Private to transfer to an Infantry Compny. Why? Because you like to hike?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I dint have no trouble if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: WARDED
dialogues.text: (grins suddenly) Or was it just because you couldn't stand to bugle?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It was a personal matter.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: That's up to the Compny Commander's discretion to decide.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (looks straight at Warden) All right. I was First Bugler at Shafter for two years. The topkick had a friend who transferred in from the states. Next day he made him First Bugler over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you asked out on account of that!?

dialogues.speaker: PREY
dialogues.text: Maybe I just ain't sensible... But that's the reason.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (snorts) His feelings were hurt! Kids they send us now! Warden swings his chair around, absorbs himself in work a his desk as if the Prew situation is too absurd to concer himself with. Holmes speaks blandly, winningly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I've got a mighty sour Company Bugler here... but I suppose you wouldn't want that job.

dialogues.speaker: PREY
dialogues.text: No, air.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, we'll get your stripes back for you, maybe an extra one for good measure. You know why you were sent over here when you requested transfer?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDS
dialogues.text: I pulled a few strings. I'm the Regimental Boxing Coach, Prewitt. I saw your fight with Connors in the Bowl year before last. With any luck you should have won it. I thought for a while, in the second round, you were going to knock him out.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (tense) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) My Regiment got beaten last year in the finals, as you know. (savage insistence) But I mean to win this year. And I will. All I've needed was a top middleweight. (waves at pictures) Next year I'll hang your picture up there with the others, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, air. But I quit fighting. HOLMES. Quit fighting? When? what for?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I just stopped, sir... After -- Maybe you heard about what happened...

dialogues.speaker: HOLMEB
dialogues.text: You mean that fallow you hurt -- the one that went blind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew's lips are drawn tight. He nods almost imperceptibly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this shot Maggio can be seen in b.g. through door Orderly Room. He pretends to be sweeping, but stops now a then to listen.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Yes, it's too bad about that. I can understand how you feel. But those things happen in this game. A man has got to accept that possibility when he fights.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That's why I decided I would quit, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (less warmly) But on the other hand, look at (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLMES(cont'd) it this way. What if all fighters felt like that?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: They don't.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Would you have us disband our fighting program because one man got hurt?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No, sir. I dint say --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You might as well say stop war because one man got killed. Our fighting program is the best morale builder we have off here away from home.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I don't want it disbanded, sir. (doggedly) But I don't see why any man should fight unless he wants to.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It looks to me like you're trying to acquire a reputation as a lone wolf, Prewitt. You should know that in the Army it's not the individual that counts. If a man wants to get ahead he has certain responsibilities to fulfill that go beyond the regulations. It might look as though I were a free agent, but I'm not. Nobody is. Holmes waits hopefully for a moment, then realizes Prew i not going to respond further. He stands. Prew snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll change your mind. In the meantime just don't make any mistakes in my outfit. (to Warden) I've got to go into town. Is there anything else for me today, Sergeant?  10.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (holds up papers) Yea, sir! The Compny Pond Report's got to be made out. It's due tomorrow --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You make it out. Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (holds up more papers) No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is, you fix it. If there's anything that has to go in this afternoon, sign my name. I won't be back. He goes out, crossing Warden's desk and knocking a wire basket filled with papers on the floor. In a moment, the sound of the screen door slamming is heard. Warden picks the papers.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: He'd strangle on his own spit if I weren't here to swab out his throat for him. (to Prew) Come on. I'll show you the Supply Room. Warden goes out to Orderly Room, Prew following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden enter and walk through. Maggio bobs hi head approvingly at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they come out of the Orderly Room. Prew hoists his barracks bags to his shoulders, balancing them delicately CAMERA TRUCKS with him and Warden as they walk down the porch.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (one of his unexpected intense bursts) Know what you did just now? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WARDEN(cont 'd) When you turned down Dynanite Holmes' boxing squad? You put your head in a noose. Things are soft for a boxer in his Compny. Otherwise, you better know how to soljer.

dialogues.speaker: PHEW
dialogues.text: I can soljer with any man.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: This ain't the Bugle Corps -- this is straight duty.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances. A convertible, top down, drives by and pulls up outside t Orderly Room. KAREN HOLMES, a tall, lean blonde woman, ge out. Her skirt hikes up a little as she goes up the stair the Orderly Room. Warden and Prew stop walking and watch Karen stops, glances at Warden momentarily, then goes int the Orderly Room.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Since when is this place gettin to be the Royal Hawaiian?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: His wife. Captain Holmes'. They resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You'll fight, Prewitt. You'll fight because Captain Holmes got a bee in his hat he needs a winnin team to make Mayor. And if you don't do it for him you'll do it for me. I only been in this outfit eight months myself but I learned one thing. My job is to keep him happy. The more he's happy the less he bothers me and the better I run his Compny. So we know where we stand, don't we, kid?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I know where I stand. I don't believe that's the only way a man can get along. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREW(cont 'd) A man's got to make up his own mind and go his own way. It he don't, he's nothin...

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Maybe back in the days of the pioneers a man could go his own way. But not in our time, kid. Today you got to play ball. You got to divide it all by two. They have reached a Dutch door, top half open. A sign ove reads: SUPPLY ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPPLY SERGEANT LEVA is eating a candy bar with one hand leisurely typing up a form with the other. He is a foolis looking man, about thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Lava! Can't I once walk by this Supply Room and find you workin with both hands!

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: (comes up to door) I can't do no better on what you people pay me.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Draw some supplies for this man. (to Prew) That's G Compny barracks over there. Get rid of your bags and come back here, and Leva'll find you a cart to lug your stuff over in. Save you makin four five trips.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (surprised, pleased) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I just hate to see energy wasted. Any kind. Besides, you'll be needin yours. Prew walks off, toting the barracks bags. The bang of the Orderly Room door is heard and Lava and Warden look in th direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she walks along porch toward them. She is at a considerable distance. Karen is about thirty. She wears a  13. sweater and skirt. She is aware the men are studying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching Karen. Leva leans over the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: Her and them sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she continues toward them. As much as a man can make o she is probably not wearing a brassiere. Warden's and Lav voices, loud at first, get softer and softer the nearer K gets to camera. At end of the shot, as she is only a few yards away, they are practically whispering.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Army women... They're cold, they got no more warmth than a diamond. There's no pleasure in them...

dialogues.speaker: LEVA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but this one knows the score... Like I been tellin you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: LEVA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay, not around here. But I was back at Fort Bliss with Holmes. When they was married only a year or two. I heard plenty about the lady then. Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You heard.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay, never me. But a lot of them. I know some of the Use she played ‘around with, don't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I ain't tellin you. You're tellin me. Karen stops, a few paces from camera.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lava watches, listens avidly but discreetly in b.g. Durin the dialogue, Karen seems irritated by Warden, who looks her coolly, appraisingly, physically.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for my husband.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Captain Holmes just went in town, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course, He was to have left some things for me. (stumbles slightly) That he was to have purchased. Do you know anything about them?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, I don't. Is there anythin I can do for you? KAREN. No, thanks, Sergeant. She makes slight move to go, pauses.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's been telling me quite a bit about you lately. My husband. He says you're very efficient

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What is it that makes you so efficient, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I couldn't help it if I was born smart, ma'am. Karen laughs suddenly, loudly.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I love that. Well, good-bye, Sergeant. Karen turns and walks back up the porch toward her car. Warden and Leva watch her. when she is out of earshot Lev speaks.  15.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: But man, she sure is one, ain't she?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: One what?

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: One woman.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly) I've seen better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT 22 Karen, in a negligee, is seated at a dress table, brushing her hair -- steadily, gracefully, enjoyin the sensual pleasure of it. Karen is a woman of moods and tempers, spontaneous, quick to impulse. A car is heard pulling strokes opening answer. Through up in the driveway, the motor stopping. Karen's brush become faster, rougher. The front door is heard and Holmes' voice calling, "Karen." She does not Holmes enters. He seems to have had a few drinks. the following, Karen continues brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm so late. And about dinner, I --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: -- I got tied up with General Slater. Bumped into him at the Officers' Club.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes? What did the General have to say?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Success, he said. Success in war, success in peacetime... And not a word about my promotion... There are times I think the Old Man's just waiting to ship me down... (slumps into chair) I've had a bad day all around... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLMES(cont'd) started right off this morning... trouble with a new man...

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: If you'd spend less time buttering Generals and more time with your Company, maybe you'd get that promotion.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDS
dialogues.text: The Company takes care of itself. Or my Topkick takes care of it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I went over there this morning looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (flustered) I had some business to attend to in town. During the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (unemotionally) From the way you look I gather your business wasn't too successful.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Now what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Dana. Give me credit for a few brains.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: How many, times do I have to tell you I haven't any other women before you'll believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen laughs sharply, loudly, then stops suddenly as she looks at herself in the mirror, sees the repugnance in he face. She puts down the hairbrush, picks up a long comb.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES VOICE
dialogues.text: If it were so, don't you think I'd admit it? The way things are between us now? What right have you to always be accusing me?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What right?  17. They are both tense now. Holmes is out of the chair and pacing. Karen combs her hair spasmodically.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: That again. How long will it be, I wonder, before I'm allowed to live that down? After eight years, how many times do I have to tell you It Was An Accident?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That makes it all right, I suppose!

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. I know what it's done to you, but --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You know I hate to talk about it! He moves over to her.

dialogues.speaker: HOLM ES
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you I'm sorry, about that? How many times that I had no way of knowing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hands on her shoulders. Karen shakes away, ri faces him.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You had a way of knowing, Dana. I want to go to bed. Please get out of my bedroom. Holmes looks at her sullenly, then exits to adjoining roo closing the door behind him. There is a moment of silence then a sharp snap as Karen breaks the comb in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is fairly well filled with soldiers. The click o pool balls is heard over shot. Warden is reading a newspaper.. A column heading, conspicuous in shot, reads: JAPS ADVANCE IN CHINA. Warden drops the paper on his lap looks toward pool table, squinting thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio, Prew and CHIEF CHOATE, a Corporal, are playing po Choate is a full Choctaw Indian, a man of great bulk and tolerance. He speaks in a tremendously deep bass voice. T  18. table on one side is surrounded by the prizefighters of G Company. They are IRE GALOVITCH, an ape-like, bent-kneed weighing about two twenty, with a widow's peak almost to eyebrows; BALDY DHOM, chunky and tough, his head as bald an orange; TURP THORNHILL, a stringy, chinless Mississipi HENDERSON, a tall, hard Texan; CHAMP WILSON, wiry and goo looking. They are all Sergeants except Wilson, who is a Corporal. The men have been heckling Prew and are watchin with cold belligerence. Choate, bending over his cue, sho and misses.

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: I'm coldern a Idaho winter tonight. Prew shoots, makes a brilliant shot.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Man, what I would not give to have this character in the corner poolroom in my home town: I'd dress him up on overhalls and a straw hat and put a grass in his teeth, and I would make a whole mint of ghelt off him! Choate laughs deeply. Prew sizes up a new shot.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: We'd of won last year if we had a good middleweight. You box as good as you used to over at Shatter we're a cinch this year. Prew doesn't respond. He bends over his cue again.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: You ain't forget the Division champs get ten day furloughs, did you, son? Ey?

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: You no talk now, Prewitt. But out in field with us you sing different song. An don't think you are tough guy. Quickest way to stockade is being tough guy.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: You heard him. Better think it over.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Lissen, it's his right not to fight if he don't want. Without bein kicked around. Now, we playin pool. Whyn't you take off?

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: You want a busted head, Maggio?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (seriously) No.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: Then keep your big nose out altogether. (turns back to Prew) Trainin season starts next week -- Prew has been growing more and more agitated, as much by inner turmoil as by the men. His control snaps suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I told you I quit fightin! I'm through! An that's all she wrote: You guys want to put the screws on, go ahead. I can take anything you hand out!

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: Okay, Prewitt. No halts barred. The five men move off, file out of the Dayroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His paper still on his lap. He has been watching. He wear faint smile of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew chalks his cue, hands trembling, turns to Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I just hate to see a good man get it in the gut.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: You might as well get use to it, kid. You probly be seein it often before you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. a few of the men are moving to and from the latri but most of them are in their bunks. Over shot the sound bugle blowing Tattoo is heard. Lights are being extinguis in various parts of the room. Prew and Choate are lying o adjoining bunks, smoking. Choate's voice is almost linked his last speech of preceding scene.

dialogues.speaker: CHO ATE
dialogues.text: . oh, sure, we got a few bad non- coms and we got Dynamite Holmes for a Captain. But I been around twenty years in this Army. They even up. In b. g. Warden and SERGEANT PETE (POP) KARELSEN come thr from the latrine. The latter is a grizzled, crumbled dog- face, about fifty.

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: Take A Compny. They got the best Compny Commander I ever saw. But their Topkick -- he ain't no Warden. Warden stops beside Prew and Karelsen moves on, going in small room off the main squadroom. Warden's big, powerful body is covered only by a towel around his loins. He smil at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Hello, kid. Everythin nice and comfy?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Never better.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: ‘at's the lull before the storm, kid. Set yourself. He moves off, goes into the room he shares with Karelsen.  21.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What's the deal with him, anyway? I can't figure him. The lights are almost all off and activity in the room ha ended.

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: The Warden? He's a wild man. He was in the 15th when they seen their action in the Settlement in Shanghai. I heard about it down in the Philippes even. He got himself a DSC and a Purple Heart out of it but you'd never know it if I dint tell you. This next war comes Warden'll be right in there standin up on the skyline, trio to get himself killed, but nothing will ever touch him. He'll come through maddern, wildern, craziern ever. All I know is he's the best soljer I ever saw... The lights are all out now and the room is in darkness. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: carrying rifles, marching at attention. Prew is FEATURED shot; a light smile of pleasure as he moves along. Choate bringing up the rear, is singing the Regimental Marching in a wonderful basso. Dhom marches on one side of the platoon, Galovitch on the other. Dhom calls out the "huts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in perfect unison.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Prewitt! Get in step, Prewitt Prew frowns slightly. He hops once, changing stride, real he is now out of step. GALOVITCH’S VOICE Prewitt! Dis a drill, not picnic! Get in step!  22. Prew hops again, changing step. He marches along. Dhom's voice commands "Platoon -- Halt!" Prew and men around him come to halt.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: Prewitt! Step out! Prew steps to the front, still smiling faintly.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: You march like a drunk gooney bird! Corpral Paluso! Take this man to the track. Send him 'round seven laps double-time rifle at high port!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew running around track, his rifle at high port. He wea slightly contemptuous smile. CORPORAL PALUSO sits on the grass infield watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: kneeling over their rifles, laid out on shelter halves. P is FEATURED in shot. His shirt is wet and he is sweating heavily, as if he has just come from the run around the track. Henderson stands in front of the group, instructin

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: -- rifle's your beat friend. In case them weapons jams in combat could mean life or death. You got to know 'em inside out. Now I want you to strip them weapons and put it together again. (holds up stop watch) Go! The men start taking their rifles apart as fast as they c Henderson walks around watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stripping rifles. Prew is efficient and brilliantly fast Maggio fumbling and slow. Maggio keeps looking over at Pr admiring his speed.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he strips the rifle. (This mechanical operation should interesting to audiences; a good man can field strip the weapon in thirty or forty seconds.) Prew finishes the job CAMERA MOVES to CLOSE on shelter half where all the parts laid out.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ‘at's fair time. Now lemma see you put it together. Prew's hands start to work over rifle parts, putting them together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in Prew's hands, assembled, CAMERA PULLS BACK as Prew sta up, holding the weapon. The rest of the men are still wor over their rifles, Maggio is staring up at Prew in awe. Henderson grabs the rifle from Prew, turns his back to hi pretending to squint along barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking along barrel. SHOT FEATURES his thumb as he flips rear sight to one side. Henderson turns around and ANGLE WIDENS to include Prew. He throws the rifle at Prew, who catches it, staggering back.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: Your rear sight's way off! You'd be fifty feet off your target at three hundred yards! (to others, mockingly) That's what comes when a soljer don't know how to assemble a rifle. (to Prew) You better get down to the track and carry it around a few times. Maybe that’1l teach you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: running around track to sun, rifle held before him. The s is fainter but still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The platoon is divided into teams of two. Thornhill is th instructor. This is actual hand-to-hand training. Prew wi his rifle, bayonet fixed, in expert thrusts. Maggio is fighting in next lane. Thornhill walks behind Prew, trips quickly as he passes. Prew falls off balance. His opponen smashes his rifle against Prew’s, knocks it to the ground Prew whirls on Thornhill in protest.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: Wide open, ey, Prewitt? Maybe seven laps’1l teach you to watch yourself... Maggio, wielding his rifle madly, yells over.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hey, I saw that -- I saw what you pulled --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: toiling around track together, holding rifles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio and Prew trudge wearily along the porch, rifles on shoulders. Their sweaty uniforms are plastered to their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I use to think a shipping clerk was a dog's life. (sighs, shakes head) What I would not give to be back in Gimbel's basement! As they come up to the Supply Room, Warden, neat and cool leaning on the counter. He steps aside to let them pass beams at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Chow's almost over, men. Better hurry up and wash. ‘less of course you'd rather go in the way you are.  25. Maggio gives Warden a dirty look. Prew's expression is noncommittal. They carry their rifles into the Supply Roo Leva comes up to the door as Warden turns to go back to t Orderly Room. As he does, Karen's convertible comes down street. Warden stops, watches it.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S POV
dialogues.text: as Karen drives by, turning her head slightly toward ward There is the vaguest trace of i smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he turns to watch the departing car.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: I'm tellin you, Top, she's trouble. You better keep your mind off what you're thinkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Warden, still looking after the car, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a gloomy, rainy day and the lights are on in the office. Warden is at his desk, working. Holmes is bucklin his trench coat. He wears a happy smile.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I won't be back in time to take Retreat. (winks at Warden) Or Reveille either, probably.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (strides back and forth; jovially) All work and no play, Sergeant. All you do is sit around sweating over this paper and that. There are other things in this world beside work. Warden carries some official papers to Holmes' desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (bending over, tying shoelace) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLMES(cont'd) You ought to get out more yourself, Warden. Warden is looking directly at the picture of Karen on Hol desk.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I've been considering it. He turns aside as Holmes straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going. He claps Warden on the back fraternally.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I'm leaving it in your care, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: It'll be here when you get back. Holmes goes out. Warden turns back to Holmes' desk. He is still holding the papers in one hand. He looks at Karen's picture, picks it up with his other hand, squints at it, considering the chances very, very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing on the open porch, in the rain. He wears a GI raincoat. He is squinting at the door with the same expression he used looking at Karen's picture. He takes a deep breath as if he were going off a high diving board, knocks briskly. A shadow moves across the room behind the curtains. Then Karen opens the door. She is in shorts and blouse.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh. If it isn't Sergeant Warden. You better step inside or you'll get wet. Warden opens the screen door and jumps in past the water running off the eaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden jumps in. He takes off his rain hat  27.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I am wet.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: If you're looking for my husband, he isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (taking the long chance) And if I'm not looking for him?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (unsmiling) He still isn't here. If that does you any good.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Well, I'm looking for him. Do you know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I haven't the slightest idea. Perhaps he's in town. I guess it was ‘in town’ the way you put it wasn't it? Or perhaps he's at the Club. Having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (fishes in his pocket brings out papers) I got some papers it's important for him to sign. Today.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (turns) I'll try phoning him at the Club for you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I never like to disturb a man drinking.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (turns back) What is it you want, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I could use a drink myself right now. Bad. Anyway, I got a faint suspicion the Captain's ‘in town.’ Ain't you going to ask me in?  28. Karen finally smiles, faintly. She goes into the kitchen leaving the door open. Warden follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is small and undistinguished. Karen takes a whisky bottle from a cabinet, pours a straight, stiff dri puts it on the sink. Warden puts the papers down and drin Karen sits on a high kitchen stool.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You’re taking an awful chance, you know. My maid is liable to be home any time.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No she won't. Thursday's her day off. He takes off his raincoat, drops it on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You think of everything, don't you Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I try. In my position you have to.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (goes to sink, picks up the papers) Are these really important?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes. But not important they get signed today. Tomorrow's okay. Karen suddenly, deliberately, rips the papers in half. Th she tears them into bits and throws them into the wastebasket. Warden appreciates the gesture, relaxes for first time. He grins widely.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I got carbons of those back at the office. So it won't be much work to fix them up. Warden's control has begun to affect Karen's now. She is losing her poise.  29.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That's what I like about you Sergeant. You have confidence. It's also what I dislike about you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: It's not confidence. It's honesty.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Honesty? How did you acquire such an old-fashioned virtue?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I figgered out one day it was the shortest distance between two points.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, he's clever as well as virile.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No -- it's just that I hate to see a beautiful woman goin all to waste. He moves close to Karen, is on the verge of embracing her Greatly tempted but greatly disturbed, she turns away. Du next she pours herself a drink, the bottle shaking in her hand. Her tone is no longer brittle. It is bitter.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Waste, did you say? Now that's a subject I might tell you something about. There's we. And then there's waste. Positive and negative. The negative is sometimes more interesting... more evil. For example -- what about the house without a child? Tell me your thoughts, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You're going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not if I can help it.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Please don't cry... I can't stand to see somebody cry.  30. Karen turns to face him as he picks up his raincoat, is a to put it on.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'm leaving. Isn't that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (slowly) I don't know, Sergeant. To be honest, I don't know. They stare squarely at each other, both puzzled and a lit afraid of their emotions. This is something neither had counted on.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I know a beach near Diamond Head. Nobody ever goes there. The cars on the highway pass above and they never know it's there. You feel like you used to feel when you were a kid, hiding by yourself ina cave, watching the others hunting you. Karen turns, goes to the sink, puts the whisky bottle bac the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Maybe... why not?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: How about Payday? Karen is trying hard to regain her glassy composure. She unsmiling again.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You don't have to spend money on me, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I just like to have some on me when I take out a woman. Can you get away?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Maybe.  31. Warden grins as he puts on his raincoat. He goes to the d to the pantry, pauses there.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'll be in Kuhio Park. Say, nine o'clock. Payday. Karen leans back against the sink, watches him go out to pantry. A moment later the sound of the door is heard as leaves the house. She turns on the faucet, starts to rins the glasses they have used. Suddenly she turns the faucet full force, watches it pound into the sink. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are grouped around Holmes. He is pressing hard to pretend equanimity. The Sergeants appear somewhat baffled determined.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: -- this man Prewitt’s been here over a month now. I expected you mend have him around before this.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: We've been runnin him pretty hard. But he don't faze.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Maybe he needs a good dose of The Treatment. The men react to the phrase; The Treatment is obviously reserved for very special, intractable cases. They consid it silently for a moment or two.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: A double dose needs him to be given.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: (nods) The Treatment’1l1 bring that puppy boy around...

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You understand. I don't want any rough stuff. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLMES(cont'd) But we all know good athletes make good leaders. And good leaders -- The music of the forthcoming MONTAGE drowns Holmes' words he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MONTAGE consists of a continuous stream of SUPERIMPOS depicting Prew's growing humiliation and exhaustion at th hands of the non-corns. Mingling with the background shot are VARIOUS ANGLES of CLOSEUPS of Prew. As the speed of t sequence increases, the stubborn smile on his face gives to hurt, bitterness, anger... Over shots we occasionally stray shouts of the non-corns as they belabor Prew, but f the most part these and other dialogue are obliterated by MUSIC. The MONTAGE can be selected and created from the following:

dialogues.speaker: PATROL EXERCISES, GRENADE PRACTICE, (IF NEEDED)
dialogues.text: in all of which Prew excels.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES GALOVITCH WILSON DHOM THORNHILL HENDERSON
dialogues.text: riding Prew, mocking him, grinning at him, thumbing him t the track, etc. FEATURED is Galovitch, who takes particul Joy in baiting Prew.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES PREW
dialogues.text: running around track, staggering despite a tremendous eff not to show his fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: OBSTACLE COURSE
dialogues.text: with the platoon going through, crouched low, live ammuni spattering around them. Prew, nearest camera, is lower th any man in the line. Over shot we hear a snatch of Wilson Voice yelling at Prew to get lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson bawling Prew out, thumbing him to one side of obst course.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES PREW
dialogues.text: chinning himself on bar setup near obstacle course; he is near physical exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: OBSTACLE COURSE PREW
dialogues.text: going through alone, on his belly in deep mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coming HEAD-ON into camera as he bellies through the mud the obstacle course. Snatch of mingled voices of non-coms yelling "Keep it downs", “Get that nose in the mud!”, etc Prew is utterly spent. His face drops into the mud, which splatters up, obscuring the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bent over the sink, scraping, washing and rinsing cooking pans and mixing basins. He hangs the soap bucket on the h faucet and turns it on full force. As he does, PRIVATE WILLARD, a fat, whining cook, dumps an additional huge pi of pans before him. Prew looks at them ruefully. Willard something to him with a "hustle up" gesture. The faucet drowns the words. MEDIUM SHOT ANOTHER PART OF KITCHEN PREW AT SINK IN B.G. Men are working in the steady, helpless motion of the KP. Waiters swing in and out of the entrances leading to the halls, carrying large trays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mesa Sergeant, a tall, gaunt man, surveys the scene possessively. Maggio, Dining Room Orderly today, wearing soiled white coat, flashes by to the mess hall, almost dropping his loaded tray in his haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slow, lazy, heavy man, peeling potatoes. There is a lar kettle filled with dirty water in front of him in which t potatoes are floating. Treadwell stabs at one with a long fork, misses it. He stabs again, almost in slow motion, misses again. He sees Stark glowering over him.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: Ah+m suppose to be a automatic rifle man, not a spud-cutter.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Rifle man, huh? All somebody’d have to do would be holler war at you and it'd be over the hill and far away . Stark walks off.  34.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: ... they just give me my chance they'll see... He is surprised and pleased as he spears a potato this ti He raises it triumphantly like a caught fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faucet is still on and we cannot hear what Willard sa as he dumps more pans before Prew. However, he is obvious complaining that Prew is slow. Prew, sweating and angry, barks something back at him and turns the faucet off.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No cook ever used that many panel Not even for an officers, banquet, ladies invited! Want me to grow couple more arms?! Stark, always alert to trouble, comes into shot. Willard him and speaks with whining dignity, for Stark's benefit.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: All I ask is that you keep the pans washed up so they're clean when I need them. In order that I am allowed to cook the kind of food required for men who work hard all day and who need good nourishing food to get their nourishment.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: Hole up ‘at noise. This man’s hot as a forty-five shootin downhill.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: (terribly injured) How you think I can do my job if the Mess Sergeant takes sides with a goldbricking KP? What do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: I think you're a fat cook who can't cook. As Willard retires, Maggio pours through from the mass ha Screaming joyously, he shoves two empty platters in front him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Comin through! Comin through! Me and my table waiters! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIO(cont'd) We workin our tail off. They runnin us to death. Hot stuff! Comin through hot stuff one side! Nobody pays any attention but Prew, who smiles at him. Ma winks back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hello, Prew! Bettern being threwn in jail, ain't it? Maggio passes camera, leaving the shot and disclosing War who has entered from the mess hall in his wake. He carrie dish of eggs and sausage and is leaning against a pastry table. He is grinning lovingly toward Prew. He strolls ov to Prew. He eats through following. The smile never leave his face, broadens as the scene progresses.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You look awful tard, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working over the sink.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How do you like straight duty?. Life in a rifle compny, eh? Prew stops working, turns toward Warden.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What makes you think I mind it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as something electric transmits itself and they all stop they are doing to look over toward Prew and Warden.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I didn't say you minded it, kid. I just said you looked tard. Drawn to a fine edge.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (smiles back) I don't mind it, Top. It’s a great life, this. I find a pearl, I'll cut you in. Fifty-fifty, If you hadn't put me here, I wouldn't have had no chance to find it.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Well, well, there's a man for you. I'll see if I can fix you up with a lot more since you like it so much. How you like the garbage detail?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Thanks, Top, I've had it. You give it to me Tuesday. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (nods, as if just remembering) Well, then, how ‘bout street cleaning detail?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That, too. Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (nods) You got a better memory than me. Guess the best thing to do is leave you right in the kitchen a while, huh? He pretends to turn away, then stops, turns back

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Course if you was an ath-a-leet you wouldn't have to pull KP. Or any fatigue duty for that matter...

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (not smiling now) If you think you can push me into fightin, Warden, you're wrong. Not you and Dynamite and The Treatment. I'm twice the man you are. If you dint have them stripes I'd take you out on the green and beat you toa pulp.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (smile growing bigger) Don't let the stripes worry you, kid. I can always take my shirt off. Take it off right now.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You'd like that. You could get me a year in the Stockade for that one, couldn't you?  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: closing around a heavy mug in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden looking at Prew's hand. Warden's grin broadens wit something more than sarcasm. He is 'impressed and pleased Prew's honest anger.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Don't throw it, Prewitt. It might break on my head. And that would cost you one thin dime next Payday. Warden deliberately turns his back and walks off. Prew lo after him. CAMERA MOVES IN to FEATURE his hand on the mug grasps it tighter, then lets it fall back into the soapy water,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is blowing the bugle, sounding Pay Call. The rays of a blinding sun flash on its shiny surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bugle is heard over shot. A line of spruced-up men stretches through the mess hall. A blanket is spread over table and behind it sits Holmes, flanked by Warden and Mazzioli. In front of Holmes is a pile of greenbacks and cigar box filled with silver. He is paying out the man at head of the line.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: -- and just see you don't drink all this up in one place. The man smiles, appreciating the whimsy, salutes, moves o

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Prewitt. Prew, next in line, steps up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Robert E. Lee, RA 345071. He is crisp, sharp, expressionless. He holds out his hand for fingernail inspection.  38. Holmes looks them over, then up at the perfect knot in hi tie. He stares at Prew as if trying to fathom him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Have you given any thought to the boxing team recently, Prewitt?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (tonelessly) I feel the same way, sir. Holmes’ hands clench. He seems about to fly into a rage w he senses a motion at his side. He turns to see Warden looking straight at him. Warden's face has the same meaningfully expressionless look as Prew’s. Holmes wilts before it, turns to Mazzioli.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What's this man's pay?

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: (reading from Payroll) Private Prewitt, thirty dollars base pay. Deductions-laundry, insurance, PX checks. CAMERA MOVES IN to CLOSE SHOT of Holmes# hands laying mon out on blanket.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Total due twelve dollars thirty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Payday night. A gay, noisy jamboree. Soldiers, mostly in civilian clothes, and uniformed sailors swarm down the street. Taxi drivers arguing with their fares as they pul at bars. Filipinos padding in twos and threes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio and Prew, dressed in slacks and Aloha shirts, stan front of what looks like a renovated residence. They give evidence of having already accomplished a little substant drinking. The sound of loud piano playing is heard from within. A sign over the door reads: NEW CONGRESS CLUB - S DRINKS - DANCING - RECREATION - MEMBERS ONLY. The door op  39. and MRS. KIPFER stands at the threshold. She is a sophisticated-looking woman with upswept hair, wears an evening gown with a corsage of orchids. The piano music, louder with the opening of the door, continues through al the following. The pianist is hammering out "I Don't Want Set The World On Fire" (or a similar hit of 1941)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Greetings, Mrs. Kipfer.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: (cordially) Why, it's Angelo Maggio. He barges past her through the door. Mrs. Kipfer frowns a follows him. Prew shrugs and goes in after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew enters behind Mrs. Kipfer. The vestibule has an o South feeling of mustiness and respectability. Maggio is handing some bills to ANNETTE, a young, brash-looking gir who sits behind a reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Okay... so there y'are. Dues all paid up. Who ya got playin the piana -- a hippo?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Angelo, I don’t believe I've met your friend. And you know how I hate to find you boys in this condition...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: There. You see. Any time women see a soldier, think he's drunk. Why? You know why?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Because he is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Heavy drinking simply doesn't mix with the entertainment business. Every respectable place must consider its future.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kipfer, ma'am, I give you my solemn word your future will be safe with us.  40. Maggio nods vigorously in agreement, then pushes through heavy curtains which separate the vestibule from the room beyond. Mrs. Kipfer looks after him a little unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Angelo is one of my favorites. Annette, dear, take care of this gentleman, will you, please? Mrs. Kipfer exits through the curtains. Annette takes a c from file, picks up pen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: It'll be eight bucks, Babyface. Four for initiation fee, four for April dues.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Say, what do I get for it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: (rattling it off) Members are entitled to all privileges of the club which includes dancing, snack bar, soft drink bar, and gentlemanly relaxation with the opposite gender so long as they are gentlemen and no hard liquor is permitted. (takes a breath) Got it? Prew grins, digs in his pocket for money.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several rooms branch off from this main one. There are ab a dozen soldiers in civilian clothes -- and about a dozen hostesses. Several couples are dancing. The man at the pi is banging away, his music clashing cacophonically with a jukebox record from an adjoining room. CAMERA PANS as Mrs Kipfer moves to and fro encouraging the men to enjoy themselves. The New Congress is a sort of primitive U.S.0 place of well-worn merriment. It is not a house of prostitution but the girls look available for goosing... but one we see at the end of the PAN. She sits alone ona couch. This is LORENE. There is an innocent, child-like l about her. Her hair is done demurely in a circular roll l on her neck. She is about twenty-four. She is reading a  41. Magazine, untouched by the din around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pounding the piano as if he is trying to knock the keys o He has an enormous head and a hogshead chest. He resemble Porky Pig. His dead eyes look like two beads of caviar sp far apart on a great white plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio is attempting some serious dancing with SANDRA, a tall girl. Fatso's furious tempo and tune keep drowning t langorous tango coming from the jukebox. Maggio keeps switching his style as he tries to get out of the range o the piano but cannot. He is very annoyed. He and Sandra d out of shot, as Prew and Annette enter from the vestibule CAMERA PANS them to a trio of girls on a couch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: ... Girls, here’s some new poison. This is Billy and Jean and Nancy. The girls smile, ad-1lib hellos. Prew is looking over the girls' heads at someone in rear of room out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if she senses someone is staring at her, she looks up the magazine, smiles serenely across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she reacts sourly to Prew's reaction to Lorene. He see transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me the Princess is your style. Annette takes his arm, moves him toward two quite good- looking girls talking to a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: Meet Suzanne and Roxanne. The girls greet him heartily but Prew is looking back ove his shoulder at Lorene. Annette plucks his sleeve with haughty disdain.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: Much as I adore your company, you must allow me to tear myself away. I see a few friends at the door (snaps) Also I can see I will be of no use to you much.  42. She walks off. The other girls resume talking to the sold Prew continues to gaze across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: smiling back. Her head tilts up slowly as if someone is coming toward her. Prew comes into shot and stands before her, tongue-tied. She pats the couch. Her voice is low- pitched, poised.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (sitting) Oh... sure.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I'm Lorene.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (enchanted by the name) Lorene...

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you in here before. Prew gestures with the membership card.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I dint know about this place till now. A friend of mine brought me. We're stationed at Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Oh. Somehow I didn't think you were a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (bridles a bit) Well, I am. And I'm in for the whole ride. I'm a thirty-year man.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I suppose it's different when a fellow is going to make a career of it.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: There ain't anythin wrong with a soljer that ain't wrong with everyone else. Lorene smiles her fatal smile at Prew's seriousness.  43.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I like you just the same. I liked you the minute I saw Annette bringing you in.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (melts) Me, too. I mean when I came in. I saw you over here -- There is a commotion across the room. A group of man and girls are surrounding the piano. Fatso has stopped playin and a shouting argument is going on between him and Maggi Prew looks over, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'll play loud as I want, ya little Wop! A babble of voices drowns out Maggio's reply.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Friend of mine. (rises) You wait right here for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (smiles sweetly) Surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where two men are holding Fatso and three girls are restraining Maggio. The others are amused by the quarrel, Fatso and Maggio are deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Mess with me, Fatstuff, I'll pull you apart!

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: You're the kind of character I eat for breakfast, ya little -- Maggio breaks away from the girls and rushes toward Patso Prew, stepping through the group, grabs him. Mrs. Kipfer bustles into the melee.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPFER
dialogues.text: Now, you gentlemen know I will not have any of this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Shut up, you Wop, he says to me!

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Little Mussolini here tryin to tell me what way to play the piano.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yeah, my ear drums fit to bust already with that noise!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPFER
dialogues.text: You man can simply leave if you're not going to behave yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Come on, Angelo, come on --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: -- Ony my friends can call me Wop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Prew hauls Maggio away from the piano.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (has been watching) You know who that guy is, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Sure, I know who he is. Whadda I care?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Fatso Judson. Sergeant of the Guard at the Post Stockade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: settling down at the piano again. He glances over in direction of Maggio with a mean smile. Then he starts to hammer the keys viciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the music starts, Maggio stiffens, turns as if to go b Prew holds tight, to his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: -- I’m tellin you, leave him be. Nets danger. I seen him nearly murder a guy once. He likes it.  45. Sandra comes over, disengages Prew's arm from Maggio's, p her own around him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: All right, bully boy, now you won the war, let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (beginning to quiet down) First I got to calm my nerves. Come on with me to a phone booth or some thin. (slaps himself on belly) Where I will unveil this fifth of whisky I got under this loose flowing sports shirt. He and Sandra start off toward an adjoining room. Prew smiles, turns back toward Lorene. The smile fades. MEDIUM SHOT FROM PREW’S POV Lorene is looking at another soldier, on the couch beside her, with her rapt, innocent expression.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT PREW
dialogues.text: as he crosses room to Lorene, hurt and disappointed. CAME HOLDS on MEDIUM SHOT as he comes up to her and the soldie talkative man named BILL.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: -- you go along as fast as forty miles per through that surf and your balance has got to be letter perfect.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Hey, I thought you were gonna wait.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (looks up, smiles) Bill here was telling me about surfboarding.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hello, friend.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (pats couch) Sit down and just listen. He describes it thrillingly. Prew sits down, disgruntled. Bill notes his expression.  46.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You know anything about surfboarding?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No. Nothing. Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You must be stationed inland then. I'm at DeRussey so I get lots of chances.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yeah? But then we got mountains. You know anything about mountain climbing?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: A little bit. Are you a mountain climber?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No. You know anything about flying an airplane? Lorene is frowning now.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I've had a few lessons.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Well, I can't fly either. What do you know about deep sea diving?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Do you want to move into another room, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sure. The air in here seems to have gotten very smelly, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yeah, I noticed that, too --

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Listen, fellow --

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Shall we go, then?  47. She and Bill rise. She smiles tremulously at him as she t his arm and they start off. She throws a severe glance ov her shoulder at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He settles lower in the couch, the picture of frustration hopelessness. He pulls a cigarette from his pocket and li it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen sits on the bench, her ankles crosses primly, very at ease. There is Payday activity here also; amorous strolling couples; men in ones and twos looking for picku Several unattached men pass Karen, ogle her. She is about get up and leave when Warden comes into shot, stands over her. His civilian suit is neat and well-cut. Both are strained, awkward, antagonistic. Now that the step has be taken they are not at all sure it was a clever one.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Why, hello. I didn't think you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm not late.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No, I guess you're not. But then I came a little early. I must have been overanxious. You weren't overanxious though, were you? You got here right on the dot.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd of been early too only I stopped to get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You certainly chose a savory spot for our meeting.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Would you rather it'd been the cocktail lounge of the Royal?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No, but I've had five chances to be picked up in the last few minutes.  48.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (sits beside her on the bench) That's par for the course around here.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, I don't care for it. I never went in much for back-alley loving.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You probably think I'm a tramp don't you?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What makes you think I'd think that?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Don't try to be gallant, Sergeant If you think this is a mistake, come right out and say so.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (outrage) Listen, what started all this anyway? Why'm I shakin inside like a school kid out with teacher Where'd I come up with a yen for of all things the Compny Commander's wife! And her actin like Lady Astor's horse all because I only got here on time! Warden's burst shatters the tension. Karen breaks into laughter. After a moment, Warden joins in.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: On the other hand, I've got a bathing suit under my dress.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Funny. I got one in a U-Drive-It parked around the corner. He takes her hand. They rise and walk away, backs to came They merge with the other couples in the little park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso's piano music o.s. Prew is slumped on the couch. He stubs out the cigarette, which is almost burnt down. He s someone coming toward him, slowly raises his eyes. Lorene comes into shot, looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How's the surfboard rider?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: That was a terrible way to have acted. What you did.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I was jealous.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (laughs) You're a funny one.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What do you dames want? To take the heart out of a man and tie it up in barbed wire?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (angry because she really likes Prew) Now, look here, what do you think Mrs. Kipfer pays us for? We're hired to be nice to all the boys. They're all alike. Is it so important?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (stands; urgently) Yes, it's important. Maybe we seem all alike but none of us is ever all alike. (pause) All right, I'm sorry about before.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (touched by his outburst) That piano is about to drive me out of my mind. Let's go up to Mrs. Kipfer's suite and sit there. She lets us use it sometimes... for somebody special.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Are you mad?  50.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not mad.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Because if you're still mad I'd just rather we called the whole thing off.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (takes his arm) You certainly are a funny one. They walk away from camera, merging with the others in-th room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweeping over camera, spray flying.

dialogues.speaker: BEACH
dialogues.text: A tiny beach set among rocks. The pale sand glows in the moonlight. Warden, in a bathing suit, is lighting a fire about ten yards from the water's edge. Karen is just step out of her dress; her bathing suit is underneath. A coupl GI blankets near the fire. Her teeth are beginning to cha in the chill of the night air; she raises her arms to the longingly, happily.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I hope the ocean's ice cold. I hope I freeze in a solid chunk.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (sudden, intense laugh) Just so long's you melt afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I love the way you laugh. He stands, moves to her. She laughs, turns and runs into water. He runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: near shore, as Karen dives into it. Warden follows her. T wave washes over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLED so we see only back of the divan. We hear s chuckles from Prew and Lorene o.s., then silence for seve moments. CAMERA MOVES as we hear a few more low, intimate laughs, then Prew and Lorene are disclosed on the couch their heads close together as if they have just kissed pleasantly but not passionately. Mrs. Kipfer's living roo on the order of the vestibule; it, too, has a faded laven feeling. A door leading to another room is half open in b A door leading to a hall is closed. Prew's arm is around Lorene's shoulder; he is very relaxed, regards her with something like wonder. Lorene is mellower, too, making no effort now to be "the Princess." She speaks as if resumin conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I enlisted, too. I came out here on my own. To get away from my home town. In Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I had a boy friend. I was a waitress. He was from the richest family in town. He just married the girl suitable for his position. After three years of going around with me. (pause) It's a pretty story, isn't it? Maybe they could make a movie of it.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: They did. Ten thousand of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: So I left and went to Seattle, asa waitress. And I met a girl just back from Hawaii. She said she'd made a lot of money working for Mrs. Kipfer. I caught the first boat. I've been here a year and two months.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You like it much?  52.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't like it. But I don't mind it. Anyway, I won't be here forever.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No. Sure not. I mean, why should you?

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I have it all figured out. In another year I'll be back home, with a pile of bills big enough to choke a steer. And then I will be all set for life -- There is a sound at the door and they turn towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it opens slowly and a disembodied arm pokes through, i hand gripping the neck of a whisky bottle. After a moment Maggio's head follows the arm through the door. He is grinning like an amateur conspirator.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I dint hear no sounds of combat. So I figgered maybe you'd like a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Maggio comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Or otherwise old Sandra would of drank it all by herself. She's a fine girl. But she drinks like a fish. There are glasses on a cupboard near the divan. Maggio se three of them up, starts to pour whisky into them.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I never drink much. Maggio stops short of the third glass. He takes a big gul from the first.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: I think it' a a weakness.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (another gulp) I grant you that.  53.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: And I don't like weakness. (to Prew) ) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No. I don't like weakness. (rises, takes a drink) But I like to drink. He comes back to the divan.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: With you it's not a weakness. With you it's more like a virtue.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: That sounds like a very profound remark. Maybe that's why I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: (snuggles to Prew) Well, it's so.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hey! What you gonna do, marry this guy? Way you grinnin at him you look like his wife!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Get outa here!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (picks up bottle) Okay. Back to old long-legged Sandra. I love 'em tall. Acres and acres. He goes out, closing door behind him. Suddenly the door o again and Maggio pops back in. He puts the whisky bottle table next to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Enjoy yourself, pizon. You need it more than me. You be back with The Treatment tomorrow. He pops out again, the door closing after him. Prew's gai dims with the reference to The Treatment. Lorene sees thi Prew rises, goes to whisky bottle.  54.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That was nice before. The way you snuggled up. In front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: What's he mean, The Treatment? Prew doesn't answer. He pours a drink, gulps it.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: What did he mean?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Some of the guys puttin me over the jumps because I won't fight.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Fight?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: On the boxing team. I don't want to fight! I don't want to talk about it! I don't want to think about it. And they make me think about it. Every day. He drops down on the divan beside her.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It's a personal thing... His dread of telling the tale crumbles before his overwhelming need to tell it, to have someone understand.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Over at Port Shafter... I used to fight... Middleweight. I was pretty good. I used to work out with Dixie Wells. He was a light-heavy, but he was fast... And good. He loved boxing. He was gonna come out of the Army and go right into the upper brackets... People on the Outside had their eye on him. (rises, paces) Dixie didn't want, to use the six ounce gloves this time. And we neither of us wore headgear, anyway. I was set flat on my feet when I caught Dixie wide with this no more than ordinary solid cross. Dixie just happened to be standing solid, too. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREW(cont 'd) (sits on chair) From the way he fell I knew. Dead weight, square on his face. He dint roll over. He was in a coma a week. Then he finally came out of it. The only thing was that he was blind... (rises, paces) I went up to the hospital to see him. Twice. Then I couldn't go back. We got to talking about fighting the second time. And Dixie cried... Seein tears comin out of those eyes that couldn't see... There are tears on Prew's face. He turns away from Lorene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene, very moved, goes to him, stands behind him, puts hand on his shoulder. Prew does not turn but his hand gra hers. CAMERA MOVES TO CLOSE SHOT of the hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave sweeps by camera, Karen and Warden riding it into shore. CAMERA PANS with them as they walk out of the wate hand in hand. They stop at edge, as if by a mutual impuls He swings her to him and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they kiss. The embrace is impassioned. When their lips separate, their arms remain around each other, holding ti to something they find is more than sex alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Karen and Warden kiss again, a tenderness in him not s before and which he normally takes great pains to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as their lips separate again.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
