dialogues.text: Nobody ever kissed me that way... not really... They are both disquieted by the quality of their reaction the kisses. The jump to banter is a quick defense.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Nobody? CAMERA MOVES WITH them as they walk to the fire. Karen sm at him.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No. Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Not even one? Out of all the many men you've been kissed by?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Well, that will take some figuring. How many men do you think there’ve been? CAMERA HOLDS as they sit, beside the fire. Karen wraps on the blankets around her.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. Can't you even make me a rough estimate?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not without an adding machine. Do you have your adding machine with you?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No, I forgot to bring it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Then I guess you won't find out, will you?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I already know. The defense has given way and there is no mirth in the questions and answers now.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What are you hinting at?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Why? Is there something to hint at?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe a lot. Or maybe you just think there's a lot.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I do. Maybe there's been a long line of beach parties --  57.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You must be crazy -- !

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Am I? Listen, baby, maybe not here. But what about when you and Holmes were at Fort Bliss? Karen flings off the blankets, snatches her dress, stands raging. She speaks as she pulls the dress over her head wriggles into it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I had to go and forget you were a man -- with the same rotten filthy mind the rest of them have. For a minute I had to convince myself you were different --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Only it's true, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes, it's true! A part of it, some small part of whatever sewage you've been listening to. Some day perhaps you'll get all the story.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (yaps up) All what story?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You're getting to sound so much like a typical male. So you just sweat it out like a typical male. She starts toward the rocks at the end of the beach, walk fast, then almost running. Warden runs after her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden catches up with Karen. He grasps her arm roughl hauls her down onto the sand. He stares at her bitterly, waiting f or her to speak.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: All right. I've never told it to anyone before. But I think now is the time. I'll tell you the whole bloody messy thing. You can take it back to the barracks with you.  58. She speaks rapidly, pouring it out in bursts. For much of story her face is in shadow, as if a cloud is passing acr the moon.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'd been married to Captain Dana E. Holmes two years. Only he was a First Lieutenant then. Back at Fort Bliss. We lived right on a little lake where we could fish and swim and be alone, our ‘dream cottage’... I'm sure you must be able to picture it. It was off ona back road, four miles from the highway. Two miles from a neighbor and a telephone.... (pauses, then rushes on) I hadn't been married long when I knew my husband was stepping out on me. But -- you get used to that. Your mother tells you that it's life, that i t happens to a lot of women. Of course, she doesn't tell you until after it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reacting with fury toward Holmes, compassion for Karen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Then, by that time, you're pregnant. And at least you've something else to hope for. I think I was almost happy that night the pains began. Even though they were weeks too early, a whole month too early. I remember Dana was putting on that dapper silk gabardine uniform he used to wear. He was going to an officer's 'seminar.' He was kidding me about false labor. I didn't think it was humorous. I told him to get home early, to bring the doctor with him. He smiled tenderly and told me about the psychic reactions of women to pregnancy. But never fear, he'd be back early. And maybe he would have... if the 'seminar' hadn't been with the hat-check girl in one of the night clubs.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Listen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He was only a little drunk when he came in... at five a.m. He looked alarmed when he saw me. I guess it was because of my screams. I was lying there on the floor, you see -- No, don't say anything. I'm not finished yet. Of course, the baby was dead. It was a boy. But they worked over me at the hospital and fixed me up fine. They even took my appendix out, too. They threw that in free. It was all fine.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen. Please.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: And, of course, one more thing no more children. Do you know what that means? You're not a woman. You're not anything. You're a gutted shell... Sure, I went out with some of the men after that. A few months of it. I'd been made dirty and I wanted to be clean. You can see that, can't you?... Anyway, I got my revenge on Dana. I kept on living with him.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: The hateful, miserable --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You hunt so hungrily for love... love, if you can find it, you think, might give things meaning again.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Listens Listen to me --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: All right. I'm listening. Warden shakes his head, inarticulate with his rage and lo Karen moves closer to him.  60.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I know. Until I met you I didn't think it was possible, either FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Over shot soft strumming guitars and two voices singing a quiet blues. There are scattered groups,about fifteen men all -- playing pool, ping-pong, reading, writing letters talking. CAMERA REACHES PRIVATE SAL ANDERSON and Friday Clark, playing the guitars and singing. Clark plays only passably, but Anderson is highly accomplished, effortless sounding off chord progressions in diminished minors. Fri the bugler, is about twenty-four, with shy, trusting eyes Anderson is the same age, also quiet, non-aggressive. CAM CONTINUES PANNING, PASSES a soldier reading a newspaper w shakes his head and mutters, "... ain't it terrible about Gehrig dyin...", then MOVES IN to HOLD on a group at a wi seat, bulling. Prew is stretched out wearily, looks as if he's been through another recent dose of The Treatment. Maggio perches in the frame of the window like an aggress robin. Treadwell slouches at the end of the seat. Pete Karelsen is in a chair nearby, reading a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: . Ah'm in the Army because Ah can live better on the Inside than on the Outside.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It ain't the reason I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Now he's gonna give us that snow about bein a Thirty-Year Man again.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That's right. Look at Karelsen there. Only seven years more for rockin chair money. Karelsen hears his name, looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA AT ANGLE so we see he's reading a full-page advertisement featuring a girl in a revealing negligee. H feeling sorry for him;elf.  61.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: The Profession wears you down though, young man. Down thin like a knife what's been honed and honed. All that good steel just rubbed away... He turns back sadly to study the figure of the girl. MEDIUM SHOT FEATURING ANDERSON AND CLARK OTHERS IN B.G. Anderson peels off a flourish as he and Clark end their s

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: Man, that's blues! Where'd you drag that one up Prom?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (bashfully) Oh, just stumbled on it. He strums aimlessly again. Prew and Treadwell come over t listen, prop themselves on chairs. During following, seve others stroll over and a soldier writing at a desk nearby stops, turns to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: warmed by the friendliness of the music and the moment.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: They got Truckdrivers’ Blues... Sharecroppers’ Blues... Bricklayers’ Blues... We oughta have a Soljers’ Blues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Anderson repeats a theme he has happened on. It has a haunting melody.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Hey, look... I betcha we could make one out of what you just played. Do that again. Anderson repeats the melody.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I could bring it down to a third line major ending... Regular twelve bars blues.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: I bet I got two hundred blues records back home. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TREADWELL(cont 'd) But there ain't one could touch that. And that includes Saint Louis. And it could be ours... The men wear pleased smiles, delighted by the idea of possessing something quite rare and truly their own. Prew flips his cigarette into a can.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I got it. We call it the ‘Re- enlistment Blues’! There is a chorus of approval.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Lookit, we could start it with the guy getting discharged. (reaches over to desk) Hey, fella, can I use this? The soldier at the desk nods, and Prew takes his pencil a paper. He writes down the words of the song as they are composed during following.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How's this? 'Got paid out on Monday... Not a dog soljer no more... They gimme all that money....' He stops, stuck. Anderson plays the melody and Prew sings words to this point. Friday Clark chimes in suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: 'They gimme all that money... So much my pockets is sore...' They laugh. Anderson sings. Prew writes furiously.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: ‘More dough than I can use. Re- enlistment Blues...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson plays a series of chords, then repeats the last lines as the whole group joins in.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: ‘More dough than I can use. Re- enlistment Blues...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raucous, hammering music sweeps away the melancholy blues the floor of the gym Dhom is punching the bag. In a corne the raised ring Ike Galovitch is skipping rope. In the ce of the ring Thornhill and Henderson are sparring. Holmes hovers beside them, issuing instructions in a strident vo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in fatigue clothes, on his knees, scrubbing the flo There is an expression of stubborn hate on his face. Abov his head in the shot are Galovitch's feet jumping the rop In b.g. of shot is Wilson, seated near ring. GALOVITCH’S VOICE Some day you get sense in your dumb head, Prewitt, you be up here instead down there! A fine spray of spit accompanies the words and showers ov Prew but he keeps about his work.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Still makin out you like it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RING
dialogues.text: There are two water buckets near Galovitch. He skips near of them, kicks it. The bucket falls on its side and dirty water spills over the ring and down onto Prew.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Clean up dis mess, Prewitt! Prew gets to his feet. Galovitch resumes skipping rope.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: And look a life, hurry it up. You on fatigue detail, not vacation. Prew climbs into the ring, gets on his knees, starts to s up the canvas. He is nearly finished when Galovitch "accidentally" kicks over the second bucket.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Clean up, Prewitt! Prew suddenly stands, no longer able to contain his rage. throws his sponge and scrubbing brush on the ring floor

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Clean it up yourself!  64.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: How? What!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You heard me -- rub your own nose in it a while!

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: What! Prew starts out of the ring. Holmes intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Prewitt? You know better than to talk back to a non-commissioned officer.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But I have never liked being spit at, sir. Even by a non- commissioned officer.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I think you owe Sergeant Galovitch an apology.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (recklessly) I don't think I owe him no apology. In fact, I think one's owed to me.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (furious) Sergeant Galovitch, take this man to the barracks and have him roll a full field pack, extra shoes helmet and all, and then take a bicycle and hike him up to Kole- Kole Pass and back. And see that he hikes all the way. And when he gets back, bring him to me.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Yes, Sirr. Prew climbs out of the ring, Galovitch following him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Par below in the shot are Prew, hiking, and Galovitch, ri behind him on the bicycle. The dirt road is steep and the pours down, steaming hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew is hunched under the seventy-pound pack as he plods along. He is sweat-soaked, puffing, dog-weary. Galovitch' bicycle is just behind him; he runs the wheels up on Prew heels.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Move along. You not half way yet. Three more miles to top. A jeep rounds a curve a couple of hundred yards above and moves down the road. It slows its speed and pulls up when nears Prew and Galovitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeep is driven by an enlisted man. Sitting next to hi MAJOR GENERAL SLATER. Galovitch hops off the bike and he Prew snap to attention. General Slater leans out of the vehicle. He seems puzzled and interested by the odd sight the two men.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SLATER
dialogues.text: At ease. Where’re you men headed?

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Top of pass, Sir. This man insubordinate. The Captain is teaching him lesson.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SLATER
dialogues.text: (frowns) What's your outfit, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Company G, 219th, Sir. The General, still frowning slightly, nods. He signals hi driver to move on. The jeep starts down the road. Galovit gets on his bicycle. Prew starts hiking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew and Galovitch are standing in front of the Captain's desk. Prew is at attention, the heavy pack on his back; h face is drawn and tired; his clothes are plastered to him has regained his old expressionless look. Warden has swun his chair around and is surveying the scene. Holmes looks  66. Prew up and down, half-smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I take it you're ready to apologize to Sergeant Galovitch now.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No, sir, I'm not. Holmes' face sets; he jerks his head toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Take him back up there again Galovitch. He hasn't had enough yet.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: (nods unhappily, sick of bicycling) Yes, air. Prew about-faces and goes out. Galovitch follows. MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT FEATURING WARDEN HOLMES IN B.G. Warden watches Prew go out, then looks toward Holmes whos back is to him. Disgust is reflected on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes slams his fist on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: 1 know that kind of man! He’s an againster. A bitter-ender. You can't be decent to a man like that. You have to tame him, like an animal! (to Warden) Warden, I want you to prepare court martial papers. Insubordination and insolence to an officer.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Warden swings around to his own desk. He thinks for sever moments, tries to sound quite casual.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Too bad you got to lose a middleweight like that...

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Why? Do you see any other way of breaking him?  67.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I don't know... But even if he only gets three months, he'll still be in the Stockade when the boxing finals come up. He looks over at Holmes, sees him scowling, weakening.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: How about just giving him a good stiff Compny punishment for now? Holmes ponders the situation unhappily, rubs his hand ove his face,. shakes his head as if the whole thing is too m for him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: All right, all right. But throw the book at him.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (pleased but impassive) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is trimming his moustache.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'm sick of it! They ain't got no right to keep breakin it off in that kid! Sooner later Holmes is going to hound him right into the Stockade! CAMERA PULLS BACK, REVEALING Karelsen across the room, undressing tiredly, achingly. Warden is sharp and bluster using Karelsen as an escape valve. During following he go to his footlocker, opens it, takes out whisky bottle, dri

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'm through! I'm turnin in my stripes. I mean it, Pete. I could transfer out tomorrow. In Grade -- get that? To half a dozen Compnys in this Regmint!  68.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. I could be Chief of Staff, too, except I can't stand leaving all my old buddies. Karelsen is naked now except for a bath towel knotted aro his middle. He slips his feet into Japanese-style, wooden clogs, starts slowly for the door.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Where you going, Little Sir Echo?

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: To take my stinkin shower, if the First Sergeant's got no objections. Where'd you think? To the movies in this towel?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (grins) Hurry up. Let's go over to Choy's for some beer and tear up all the tables and chairs.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: (smiles, moves faster) Okay, Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aged Chinese, at least seventy-five, OLD CHOY has a lo white beard and wears a black skull cap and an embroidere robe. He is motionless, surveying the pandemonium which w hear over shot: the sounds of men laughing, talking and shouting blend with jukebox music blasting Chattanooga, C Choo. YOUNG CHOP, Old Choy's son, passes; he is thirty, w aproned, bustling, Americanized. CAMERA PANS WITH him, DISCLOSING the small beer-house; it has unpainted cement walls and a cement floor; the only thing that might be ca decorative is the jukebox. The place is crowded with men Schofield, a raucous assemblage; everyone is drinking bee and the smoke hangs in thick layers. At a table near the sit Prew, Maggio, Clark, Anderson, Treadwell and Mazzioli a corner table behind a forest of beer bottles and cans a Warden, Stark, Karelsen and Chief Choate.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: : China's the place. Your money's worth ten, twelves times as much. I'm gunna ship over soon as my time's up in this pineapple Army.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: (pinching beer off his nose) The Canal Zone for me. This girl down there. She was a planter's daughter, see. She lived a very sheltered life. A very moral young lady, Milt. I took her out toa high class dinner and then dancing. It was a great shock to her to learn about life. But she took it well. She got to like me very much after that.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: The last time I heard it you told it different.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: Well, what did you expect? I was in a different mood, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio, Anderson and Treadwell are comparing snapshots fr home, spreading them out on the table. Mazzioli is talkin Prew with great earnestness.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: it's in regulations. You've got a right to complain. You've got a right to take your case to the Inspector General. Any soldier has even a plain dogface.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I know it. I'm not complainin to nobody. They ain't goin to get the satisfaction of seein me squirm. Clark begins to play the bugle softly along with the juke music, noodling an uninspired obligato.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (pointing to pictures) believe it nor not, this is one soljer who's got a family -- look fifteen of ‘em. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIO(cont'd) See that old man with the handlebars? (proudly) Mr. Maggio is my father.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: Listen, Prew. I guess I ought not to tell you but --. Warden hasn't had you on KP much lately, has he?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Only my reglar turn.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: Well -- I was working in the Orderly Room this afternoon and I heard the Captain telling warden you're to pull KP every weekend from now on. You know what that means -- you can' t even go into town --

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Whadda they want? They done everything, now they look me in a box! what else they gonna try? Clark hits a sour note an the bugle.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (savagely) When you gonna learn to play a bugle!? In overwhelming, uncontrollable protest, Prew slaps the b away from Clark's mouth. In one motion he wipes the mouthpiece on his sleeve, raises it to his lips and blows own wild, violent obligato to the jukebox music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew plays on, the bugle's pure tone pealing through t room. Everyone puts down his beer, stops talking and turn toward Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reacting. He frowns, moved by the cry behind the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he watches and listens, an exultation for his friend nakedly revealed on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitting an almost impossibly high note, he stops as sudde as he has begun. He has played perhaps fifteen seconds in  71. all. He puts the bugle down on the table, embarrassed now the violence gone, some of the wrath unloaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is quiet for several moments, except for the continuing jukebox music, which sounds pale and thin now. Fatso Judson strolls in, stands at the door. Some of the see him, but no one greets him. Fatso threads his way bet tables as the room slowly begins to return to normal and men turn back to their beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Fatso passes. He stops, leans over Anderson's shoulder look at the snapshots on the table. He points to one pict a pretty young girl of about fifteen, posing Hollywoodish in a bathing suit, cracks his knuckles loudly.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Who's that? Who's that dame?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (impassively) My sister. Fatso whistles. He picks up the photograph, stares at it whistles again.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Whoever! Say, she's a real good piece of whistle bait! I'd sure like to get my mitts around her He laughs complacently at his own wit, tosses the picture the table, starts to move on, Maggio rises, picks up the heavy wooden stool he's been sitting on and smashes it do on Fatso's head with all his strength

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as again the laughing and shouting in the room stops abruptly. Fatso reels a little with the terrible blow but does not go down.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Why, holy -- I You hit met You hit me!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (calmly) You bet your life. (raises stool) And about to do it again.  72.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: (still blinking from the blow) What?! But what for? That's no way to fight! (reaches hand to head, brings away blood) Why, you dirty yellow sneaking -- Wop! You yellow little Wop! If that's the way you want to play! With his last sentence, Fatso whips out a knife and snaps open the blade. The blade is at least five inches long. I glints evilly as he raises it. There is a concerted whisk intake of breath from the room. Murder is clear on Fat so face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio, holding the stool high, backs up a few feet as Fa advances toward him. Men sprawl away from them.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey, it you want to fight, fight with fists. Take it outsides There is a murmur of agreement from the crowd. A couple o men are about to rise. Fatso whirls toward them.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: I'm gonna cut this little Wop’s heart out. Anybody steps in here, I give it to him first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: side by side. Old Choy watches, immobile, his slit eyes almost closed. Young Choy is shaking with fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso turns toward Maggio, who circles back around the ta as the other stalks him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (scared but brave; shouts) I'm gunna de-brain ya, Fatso! One step closer an I'm gunna kill ya! Fatso has his knife poised at his shoulder, ready to stri Warden comes into shot suddenly. He brandishes a beer bot wildly, looks like an avenging spirit of authority.  73.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Nobody's gunna do nothin! Anybody's killin anybody around here, it'll be me! Warden snatches another beer bottle from a table, now has in each hand. He steps between Fatso and Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Look outs here, Warden. This a private affair.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No it ain't! This man's in my Compny an I'm responsible for him. And you ain't makin two weeks extra paper work for me by killin him. Nor him you. Put that knife down! He smashes the neck off one of the beer bottles, points t wagged edge at Fatso, roars:

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Put it down! Fatso slowly lowers the knife to his waist, but keeps it pointed towards Maggio and Warden. Warden deliberately tu his back to Fatso, spits his words at Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Killer! You unweaned punk& Come on, you want some killing, come on! (whirls on Fatso) Come on, barrelbelly. Ain't you comin? Neither Fatso nor Maggio moves.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (with mammoth contempt) Killers! You’1l get plenty of killing, all right. More than you got the stomach for. You'll be ina war one of these days. When you feel that lead from a sniper's rifle hit you between the eyes come and tell me how you like it. Killers! (turns to Maggio) Now put down that chair. Maggio puts down the stool. Warden turns to Fatso.  74.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Throw that knife on the floor Fatso drops the knife. It clatters on the floor. There is another audible whoosh of breath from the room.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Almost scared there wasn't anybody going to stop you for a minute, weren't you? (finally lowers his voice) Is there any other little things you punks'd like me to take care of for you? He drops the beer bottles on a nearby table, strides to h own table. The room settles back, still hushed. Warden ha broken the mood of certain death, but Fatso, still facing Maggio, bites off his words with sadistic, ominous venom.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Tough monkey. Hard sister. Guys like you get to the Stockade sooner later. One day you walk in there I'll be waitin. I'll show you a coupla things. He walks away, drops into a stool at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden stands beside the table, watching. He seems satisf as Fatso moves away from Maggio. Still standing, he raise his half-filled bottle of beer, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio drops onto the stool, sidles it over to the table. half-whispers to Prew.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I made a mistake I guess, but I don't see how I could of done anything else, after that big stoop said a thing like that. Prew leans over and picks the knife off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PHEW
dialogues.text: I'll tell you your mistake. You didn't hit him hard enough to put him out.  75.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I hit him hard as I could. His head must be solid ivory. In b.g. Warden puts down the beer bottle and stalks towar the door. Maggio and Prew turn to watch him pass.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm glad he stopped it. He's a good man, you know it? As if on impulse, Prew rises and follows Warden out. EXT. CHOY’S - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew carves out. Choy's is on a wide road across from entrance to the Post. Prew looks around for Warden, sees off to one side. CAMERA MOVES WITH Prew as he goes over t him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leaning against the building, undergoing a delayed reacti to the fierce moment in Choy's. He is white-faced, sweati heavily. He looks as if he's going to be sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: astonished yet appreciative that under Warden's confidenc and control in Choy's there has been a human frailty.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: That was a near thing.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Prew holds out Fatso's knife. Warden is beginning to get control of himself; he manages a weak smile.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You keep it, kid. Keep it fora souvenir. Prew puts the knife in his pocket. They stare at one anot a few moments, each inarticulate, each wanting to express some deep emotion of respect.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You ain't enjoying life much, are you, kid?  76.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (thin smile) They can kill you but they can't eat you, Top. Warden studies Prew thoughtfully. Prew turns to go back i Choy's.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Prewitt. Prew stops, turns back

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Could you stand a weekend pass? Prew stares at him for a second, incredulously, unable to find his voice.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I thought --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You thought what, kid?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How about Dynamite?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Leave Dynamite to me. He signs most anything I put in front of him ‘thout readies it. Though Prew is overjoyed he is somehow unable to say "thanks"; Warden grins broadly at him.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I hear you gone dippy over some dame you met at the New Congress Club. He slaps Prew on the shoulder roughly.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What’d you say her name was?

dialogues.speaker: FREW
dialogues.text: Lorene...

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Pretty name.  77. Warden walks off across the street. Prew stares after him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene is covering Prew with sand and has him almost completely buried. Only his face remains uncovered. He is griming up at her. She seems thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Lorene... She throws a towel over his face. He chuckles under it.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: My name’s Alma. The chuckle from under the towel dies.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Alma Schmidt... There is a sound as of strangling from under the towel.

dialogues.speaker: LORENE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kipfer picked Lorene out of a perfume ad. She thought it sounded French... Lorene whisks the towel away. Prew's face is comic in its surprise and chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: From this point on "ALMA" will be used instead of

dialogues.speaker: "LORENE."
dialogues.text: A fashionable Waikiki night spot. An orchestra in b.g, is playing "Someone's Rocking My Dream Boat." Alma and Prew seated at the bar. She is dressed modestly and becomingly might well be taken as a society girl. Prew is wearing a civilian suit; he looks bound and choked in it.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Alma... She smiles ruefully, realizes her real name has rubbed of some of the enchantment.  78.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No, honest, I like it. Alma's a -- swell name. It was great you gettin away today.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I told Mrs. Kipfer I was sick. But I bet she doesn't believe it

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: There's no tellin when I'll get into town next. The Warden gave me a break this time. But Holmes and those others, they got me on the edge. I just about went off the deep end the other day.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You must hate the Army.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Hate the Army...?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Sure. Look what it's doing to you.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It's not the Army that's doing it It's Man. I love the Army.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Love it? Well, it sure doesn't love you in return.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: When you love something it doesn't mean they got to love you in return.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Yes, but a person can stand just so much from something --

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No! A man loves a thing, he's gotta be grateful. (pauses, gropes for thoughts) I left home when I was seventeen. Both my folks was dead, then. I bummed around. I got all sorts of jobs. I rode the rods. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREW(cont 'd) I landed in jails. I didn't belong nowhere. Until I entered the Profession. She frowns, not understanding the last word.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: The Army. I enlisted at Fort Myer and I learned how to box and I learned how to play a bugle. I never had much call for the boxing - - but if it weren't for the Army I'd never of learned how to play a bugle.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: A bugle? Prew nods. He takes the mouthpiece out of his pocket, sho it to her.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: This is the mouthpiece I used to play a Taps at Arlington. Alma takes the mouthpiece, looks it over, seems unimpress

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (as if saying "I was elected President") They picked me to play a Taps -- at Arlington Cemetery. She still looks dubious, hands the mouthpiece back. He tr desperately to communicate.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Look. Think. You ever think how strange a tree would look to one who had never lived upon the earth? Well, somehow that's how I feel when I play a bugle... There is a boisterous shouting nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, citizen! I told ya I'd meet ya, dint I? They turn and ANGLE WIDENS to INCLUDE Maggio, who has jus come up to the bar. He is in uniform. Prew is pleased to him but also alarmed; there is something near-desperate u Maggio's drunkenness.  80.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How'd you get a pass?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I dint get no pass. I just took off. I meant to bring a girl with me but --

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You better get your tail back to the Post. Right away. Maggio shakes his head violently in the negative.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I'm out for the night. I got a bellyfull. A nail, Prew. A stinkin nail. I'm thirsty for a nail. Prew gives him a cigarette. Maggio hops on an empty bar s a few places removed from Prew and Alma.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Climb up on my shoulders, Prew. You can see everythin from up here. (to Bartender) A beer. A BEER! MEDIUM SHOT AT SIDE OF ROOM TWO MPs watching Maggio, attracted by his voice and behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio talks across others at the bar to Prew and Alma.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I been in a crap game in the latrine. I win twenty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: How much did you lose?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Lose? Oh, lose. I lost twenty-seven bucks. (dejectedly) That's why I ain't got no girl. A tray on the bar contains olives, nuts and pretzels. Mag snatches up two olives, shakes them in his fist beside hi ear.  81.

dialogues.speaker: EN
dialogues.text: (rolls the olives out on bar) Snake eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew is increasingly concerned for Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You like him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (nods) He's such a comical little guy and yet somehow he makes me always want to cry while I'm laughin at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: finishing a long gulp of beer. He puts glass down on the hard.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: The Royal Hawaiian’s jist around the corner. That's where them movie stars stay. Rita Hayworth and Joan Blondell and Maureen O'Hara... You look like a movie star, Lorene... yes, you do... How long 'fore we get in the war, Prew?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe we won't get in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Tha’s what you say. He jumps off the bar stool suddenly, tears off his tie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hot in here. He throws tie on the bar, The Bartender starts to protest

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Swimming It's a great night for swimmin. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIO(cont'd) (kicks off shoes) Goin swimmin with a movie star... He is unbuttoning his shirt as he abruptly dashes away, People around are laughing at him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew watches Maggio rush out. He sees something else o which worries him. LONG SHOT FROM PREW’S POV The two MPs cross toward direction Maggio has taken. They obviously going after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma follows Prew's troubled look.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You better go look out for him, Prew glances at her gratefully, then slips off his stool. picks up Maggio's tie and shoes and hurries out after him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall pale royal palms contrast with thick dark plants and bushes. An ornamental lamppost alongside a walking path a little distance away. Prew comes into shot cautiously, carrying Maggio's tie and shoes. He moves quickly, bends over. CAMERA PANS AND MOVES IN and we see it is Maggio's shirt and trousers which Prew has discovered on the groun He looks at them wryly, picks them up, moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew, carrying Maggio's clothes, stops as he sees what lo like a shadow lying across the bench.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (calls softly) Is that you, Angelo? The shadow does not move. Prew approaches the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio is stretched out on the bench, seems to be sleepin blissfully. He is clothed only in his shorts. Despite himself, Prew smiles. He shakes the reclining figure.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Maggio, you nut. Get up. Wake up.  83. Maggio mumbles without opening his eyes or moving.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. I won't do it again. Just don't lock me up, sir. Honest, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Here's your clothes. He throws the clothes on Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (opens his eyes) Well, give ‘em back to the Indians. The Indians need clothes. All they wear is G strings.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Boy, are you drunk!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: . maybe a movie star comes outs the hotel right now and picks us up and takes us back to the States in her private plane... and installs us in her private swimming pool -- Prew pulls Maggio off the bench and starts to drag him ac the path away from the light.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (yells) Take it easy, Prew. You scrapin my tail on the sandy sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You'll get worse than that scraped - - Listen! The ominous sound of leggins brushing each other is heard not far away. Prew looks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two MPs are on the street just outside the grounds. T are still looking for Maggio, somewhat aimlessly now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew whispers to Maggio as he pulls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Come on before you're in trouble --  84. Maggio pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: I'm sick of its Can't a man get drunk? Can't a man do nothin? Can't aman put his lousy hands in his lousy pockets on a lousy street? A man gotta be hounded every minute of his life? I ain't gain to take its I ain't no cowards I ain't yellows I ain't no bums I ain't no scum! MPs! MPs! COME AND GET US!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (aghast) Now you done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two MPs came running onto the path, spot Maggio and P about thirty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio picks up his shoes, suddenly whips away from Prew runs toward the MPs. ANOTHER ANGLE NEAR MPs as they stop, surprised. Maggio is shouting, "Can't a man nothin?!" as he hurls first one shoe, then the other directly at the MPs. One MP is hit in the shoulder, stagg back. Maggio dashes between him and the second MP, but th latter reaches out and grabs him. Maggio wrenches loose b instead of running, suddenly wades in, arms swinging wild In a moment, he is hanging crab-like on the man's back. T first MP charges Maggio. Maggio grabs the second MP's clu and hits the first MP over the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified, he starts toward the fracas. MEDIUM SHOT MAGGIO AND MPs IN F.G. PREW IN B.G. The second MP has managed to get out from under Maggio. H smashes his fist into Maggio's face as the latter continu to wield the club. Maggio sees Prew coming toward them.  85.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Get back! I'm handlin this! Take off! The first MP starts to intercept Prew. Maggio tackles him around the knees and brings him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Club gone, his partner on the ground, the second UP fishe for his pistol, tugs to get it from the holster.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: This ain't your affair! Keep out of this! MEDIUM SHOT PREW IN F.G. MPs AND MAGGIO IN B.G. Prew sees the second MP raise his pistol, point it toward him. CAMERA PANS WITH him as he turns quickly and dives headlong into bushes nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES WITH him close to ground as he knees and elb his way along deep into the bushes. He stops, breathing h The sound of the MPs fighting with Maggio can be heard, t ugly sound of fists and the uglier sound of clubs smashin bone and flesh.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (screaming, crazed) Come on. Is that the best you can do? I bet you eat Wheaties, don't you? Come on... You can't even knock me out -- no matter -- Maggio's voice stops suddenly. CAMERA MOVES TO CLOSEUP of Prew on the ground, his face contorted. The voices of the are heard now, panting.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I wonder what was wrong with this guy. He must be same kind of madman.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Come on, let"s get him into a wagon. A convulsive sob escapes Prew as his head drops in the di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden is pinning some notices on a bulletin board. Prew on the bench against the wall, miserable, elbows on knees chin in hand. There is a quiet tenseness in the room. War looks over at Prew, turns back to the bulletin board. Mazzioli gets up from his desk, wanders aimlessly to a window. The screen door slams and Leva enters, eating a c bar.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: Any word on Maggio's Court Martial?

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: It's on right now. At Headquarters. Lava sits on the bench beside Prew, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: He'll get the Stockade sure. The others tense at the word "Stockade," glare at Leva as he had no right to mention it. Their fear of the place, n that it is imminent even for another soldier, is shown on their faces. There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: Maybe he won't get it. All he did was get drunk and run wild. That's a soldier's nature. It's almost his sacred duty once in a while. There is another pause. Warden barks suddenly, fiercely, Leva.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What you hangin around here for?

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: Can't a man rest himself for a min--

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What man? I can't stand to see people restin themselves. I'm eccentric. If you ain't got no work maybe I can scare you up some. Mumbling, Leva rises and goes out. Warden goes over to Pr

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Whyn't you go on over to the Day Room, shoot a little pool? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WARDEN(cont'd) I'll let you know when the word comes through. Prew looks up, nods, rises. He is half-way to the door wh the phone at the Clerk's desk rings. Prew turns. Mazzioli stares at the phone as if afraid to touch it. Warden goes over, answers.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (on phone) Compny G, First Sergeant Warden speaking... Yes, sir... Yes, sir, I will... I'll have his things in order... Yes, sir. Warden puts down phone. He looks at the waiting men.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: He got it. Six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew and a group of G Company men, including Sergeants Dh Thornhill and Henderson, are on the steps and porch as a Reconnaissance car pulls up and halts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio sits between the driver and another MP, both armed (NOTE: These are not the same MPs with whom he fought.) T Company men cluster around the car, ad-libbing greetings kidding Maggio, bucking him up. Even the Sergeants join i this; nobody likes to see a man on his way to the Stockad

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hello, men! who's got the beer?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: Okay, Brownie. Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Driver gets out of the car and goes to pick up Maggio's stacked barracks bag on the porch. Prew moves up close to Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Angelo. It's my fault. I shoulda --  88.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: You crazy. You --

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I shoulda stopped you somehow --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: It was all my party. Don't worry about it. (pronounces "e" as in "the") Anyhow, I'm gunna e-scape. If Gimbel's basement couldn't hold me neither can no lousy Stockade.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MP
dialogues.text: You heard him say SHUT UP!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO
dialogues.text: (smiles at the men) I'm a prisoner. And prisoners ain't allowed to talk. They allowed to breathe though. If they good, that is. During last speech the Driver returns, dumps the barracks in the car, and gets in. The motor starts. The men shout byes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: heartsick as he looks at Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Recon pulls out and Maggio's last hearty shout dri back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: . @-scape to Mexico and become a cowboy!...

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: as the Reconnaissance car drives through the chain-mesh g In the distance is the Stockade, a building that looks something like a country schoolhouse. Music sweeps up as gate clangs shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio walking across the yard flanked by the tall MPs. H looks around as if surveying the chances of escape. Music rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the MPs march Maggio up to a door and gesture him to e alone. He goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS from behind a man seated at a desk. Promine in shot is a wicked-looking chopped-off hoe handle lying the desk. Maggio enters, recognizes the man. He walks, up the desk, his face set in defiance. Music is rising ina fearful crescendo. CAMERA PANS just enough to REVEAL desk sign reading: "SERGEANT OF THE GUARD." The man stands up the music stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEALING Fatso Judson as the man, on his face the same murderous expression as at Choy's. He cracks his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Tough monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his eyes following a movement of Fatso’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes on Maggio, his hand gropes on the desk

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: Hard sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it finds and tightens around the hoe handle. The music sweeps in abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music of preceding shot segues into an ancient, savage Hawaiian chant which continues through following.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot covers the continuation of all the above activity. T is a native luau - definitely not for tourists. Shot incl long ditches, heated by red-hot stones and lined with lay of banana leaves, containing pig, chicken, rock crabs fish... Pots of native stew... Bowls of exotic fruit... P of raw cane... Working over the food are the natives, man the men stripped to the waist, the women arrayed in color Hawaiian costumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of male dancers swaying with the insistent beat o group of old Hawaiian instruments. This is far removed fr the night club Hula. This is a thing of swift, agile angularity, primitive and powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At end of PAN, CAMERA REVEALS Warden and Karen in the gro They are the only whites in the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her face lit by the flames. She watches the dancing breathlessly.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES TINY TOM TOM NOSE FLUTE GROUP OF MUSICIANS
dialogues.text: The native instruments playing a thin, weird melody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men laugh and grin as they dance, taunt and tease somebody o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shout and laugh and squeal with delight as they watc It is Warden the dancers are teasing. Several of the danc break out of the group, dance over to Warden, continue to prod him, apparently urging him to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: protesting, joining in the laughter. Suddenly he kicks of his shoes, rolls his slacks up to his knees. He snatches gardenia from the hair of a pretty Hawaiian girl next to sticks it over his ear, jumps into the firelight and danc with the others. The music comes up louder and faster as spectators and dancers roar.  91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all laughing as they dance, but as Warden moves them it is apparent he is as good as any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nodding, pointing at Warden, their hilarious laughter fad to delighted smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: astonished and thrilled at Warden's ability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His laughter now also diminished to a happy grin as he dances. In all he dances about thirty seconds. Then he br out of the group and runs over to Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the spectators and dancers shout their applause. Warde comes up to Karen and puts the gardenia in her hair. Kare glowing, tingling.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You just love to shock people don't you?! Where on earth did you learn to dance like that?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (panting happily) Believe it or not -- Chicago, Illinois. She flings her arms around him passionately. The onlooker howl with approval and merriment. Between Karen and Warde and camera, an enormously fat Hawaiian woman pours water the stones in one of the trench-ovens. A cloud of steam rises, hiding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING DOWN a thousand feet into Palolo Valley. Bonfire and smoke rising from the floor of the valley. The thinnest carry of the ancient Hawaiian music. CAMERA from precipice and INCLUDES Prew and Alma as they trudge shot, climbing up the steep cliff road.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT PREW AND ALMA
dialogues.text: holding hands as they walk.  92.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: -- If I dint get to see you once in a while The Treatment would've cracked me long ago. Alma, fairly winded from the climb, smiles but doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: We could have taken a cab. Except I ain't got cab fare.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: It's just around the bend. CAMERA HOLDS as they walk on around a bend in the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small house is perched precariously on the very edge the cliff. Alma and Prew come around the bend, come up to door, Prew marvelling at the house.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: This other girl and I were lucky to rent it. (proudly) It's a very fashionable district. She hands Prew her key. As he is unlocking the door:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I'll get an extra one made for you. Prew swings open the door and they go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew stops on the threshold, stares at the room in happy amazement. It is large, smartly furnished. In the rear, g doors lead to a porch. One of the panelled walls is fille with bookshelves, floor to ceiling. The bookshelves are filled with books. A hearty feminine voice calls "Hi!" fr the kitchen, and as Prew and Alma come into the room, GORGETTE enters from the kitchen. She is a very tall, ver gay, good-looking girl.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: This is Gorgette, my roommate. Gorgette, this is Prew. I told you about him.  93.

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: Don't mind me. I'm going out ina little while. Prew grins, can't keep his eyes off the astonishing books Gorgette follows his glance.

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: I belong to the Book of the Month Club. I always take every book. That way I get all the dividends. She giggles and goes off to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: She'll be great for Maggio when he gets out of the Stockade. He'll be crazy about her because she's so tall. Alma smiles, presses him into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Now you just get comfortable and I'll make you a Martini and see what's to cook for dinner. She starts oft to kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Hey. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: This is just like bein married, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder as she exits to kitchen) It's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING through smoke rising from one of the trench-oven As it clears we see the enormous Hawaiian woman and one o two others cleaning up and putting out the remnants of th fires. The merrymakers and dancers have gone; the luau is over. In b.g., quite alone, are Warden and Karen, sitting  94. the trunk of a fallen palm tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The abandoned gaiety of the earlier scene gone. They surv the emptiness. The fat Hawaiian woman comes near, rakes a over one of the dying fires. She speaks to Warden in Hawaiian. He answers her in the native tongue. The fat woman stares, shrugs, goes off.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: She said it's over -- time to go home --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Home... A beach, a car, a park... Warden puts his arm around her tenderly. He rises,

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: It'll work out...

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It can't go on like this much longer, Milt.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I know. paces a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: If there were only a way! Your lovin husband’d probly give you the divorce. But even if he didn't know what for, he'd never let me transfer.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (bucking up courage; quietly) There is a way. I've been thinking about it. Warden looks at her apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You've got to become an officer.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What !  95.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You're eligible for the extension course that came in with the draft. When you get your commission they'd ship you back to the States -- new officers aren't kept at posts where they've been enlisted men. Then --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You sure made a thorough study of it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Then I could divorce Dana and follow you and marry you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: An officer! I’ve always hated officers.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That's a fine, intelligent point of view. Suppose I said I've always hated Sergeants. That would make a lot of sense, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, thinks it over unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Okay, suppose I did it. -- And don't think it's a cinch -- the exams are tough. Then you'd be getting your divorce here while I'm in the States. We'd be apart maybe six months! We'll probly be in the war by then --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You can't be certain of that --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (snorts) Put it down on your calendar. On October twenty-third, 1941, Milt Warden told you we'd be in the war in less than a year.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (flaring) Why don't you tell the truth? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN(cont 'd) You just don't want the responsibility. You're probably not even in love with me --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You're crazy! I wish I wasn't in love with you. Maybe could enjoy life again.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't know what's happened to you -- you were honest at first --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: At first! You were tough and solid as a rock -- and now you're a whining crybaby -- He stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: And so they were married and lived unhappily ever after. They are silent for several moments.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I've never been so miserable in my life as I have since I met you.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Neither have I.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (cheerlessly) I wouldn't trade a minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (cheerlessly) Neither would I. Warden rises and paces again. Suddenly he stops, turns, l down at Karen, speaks in the same gloomy tone.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'll probably make the lousiest officer they ever saw in this Army. A happy smile creeps over Karen's face. Despite himself, begins to smile also.  97.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (fervently) You'll make a fine officer. A remarkable officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The porch is at the rear of the house, leading off from t living room. It is on the very edge of the cliff. Prew an Alma are dancing to the music of a portable victrola. It playing "Why Don't We Do This More Often?" A table still contains the dinner plates. Prew's expression holds the wonder of a child at a magic show. He misses a step stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I never caught on to dancing much.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You're a very good dancer. The record ends and Alma goes to change it. CAMERA FOLLOW Prew to the edge of the porch as he looks out over the vi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent panorama -- strings of lights in the valley across on St. Louis Heights -- in the far distance the ne of Waikiki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working with his thoughts, afraid to broach them. He ligh cigarette, his fingers trembling.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I been wanting to tell you a long time now -- (deep breath) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking through records for a new choice. She speaks quit conversationally, as if offered a pleasant compliment.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: That's nice. Because I love you, too. She puts on a record -- "It All Comes Back To Me Now." It plays throughout the sequence.  98. TwO SHOT as Alma comes over to Prew.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I mean it. I need you.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (as before) I'm glad. Because I need you, too.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (recklessly) A thirty-year man is movin all over, goin all the time. Up to now I never thought a thirty-year man had any business to think of gettin married. She stares at him, amazed, a touch angry.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: You're a funny one, little Prew boy.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (hurt) Yeah. Must be the altitude.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: A very funny one that I cannot figure out.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Why's it funny if a guy wants to marry you?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Because I'm a girl you met at the New Congress Club! And that's about two steps up from the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Okay -- I'm a private no class dogface soljer. And the way most civilians look at it, that's two steps up from no thin. There is a silence. Alma is honestly distraught.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh, Prew, Prew, I thought we were happy: Why do you want to spoil things?  99.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Lissen, I ain't think in of now. But I got a plan cookin in my head. You want to go back to the States in a year. Well, you could stretch it some, make it two years. And I could swing a Sergeant's stripes -- If I were a non-com the Army’d let me pick my duty when I re-enlist. (lost in the picture of it) And there's some posts back in the States -- like Jefferson Barracks -- The married noncoms rate solid brick houses... with lawns with new- cut grass and walks with big old oak trees...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Now I know you've lost your mind! How do you expect to become a Sergeant under this Captain Holmes of yours? It's all you can do to keep out of the Stockade!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I could fight.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: It I go out for boxin he'd send me to non-com school. The Regimental Championship is next month. I bet I could win the middleweight even without training. I used to be pretty good I could do it. Alma is deeply moved. She speaks gravely, sincerely, not all immodestly.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: No. I don't think you should give in to The Treatment... even to marry me.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: This’d be worth it.  100.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (almost desperately) Prew -- it's true we love each other now. But back in America, it might be different... We might not even want each other...

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Okay. But that ain't the real reason.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: All right. It's not.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What's the real reason you won't marry me?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I won't marry you because I don't want to be the wife of a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Well, that's the top I could ever do for you --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Because nobody's going to stop me from my plan. Nobody. Nothing. Because want to be proper.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Proper?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (impassioned) Yes, proper. Respectable. Secure. In a year I'll have enough money saved. I'm going back to my home town in Oregon and I'm going to build a new home for my mother and myself and join the country club and take up golf. And then I'll meet the proper, man with the proper position. And I'll bea proper wife who can keep a proper home and raise proper children. And I will be happy because when you are proper you are safe.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (bitterly disappointed but admiring) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREW(cont 'd) You got guts, Alma. I hope you pull it off. The victrola record ends. Alma turns away from Prew and g to the victrola. Now that shots had her say with such certainty, she deflates. Except for the fact that she loo like a girl who never cries, she looks as if she might cr She lifts the record off the turntable.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: But I do mean it when I say I need you. Because I'm lonely. Sometimes I'm dreadfully lonely... You think I'm lying, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No. Nobody ever lies about being lonely... Alma puts the same record on again. Prew looks out over t beautiful view.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: -- I've known about it for a long time! I've sensed it. And I'm not going to ignore it any longer! I want to know where you met him and just who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at breakfast in a nook off the kitchen. Holmes is a mixtu of petulance, anger and frustration. He doesn't touch his food, but occasionally takes a sip of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm not going to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You can't keep a thing like this hidden&

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm not going to hide anything. I'm just not going to tell you.  102. She applies herself to her food, anxious to drop the matt

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: One thing I know. I know it's a civilian. You'd be too discreet to pick an Army man.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't think it's any of your business who he is.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It is my business! I'm your husband! what do you think a scandal would do to my chances for a promotion? So if you're thinking of a divorce, you can forget it! Karen stiffens. She struggles to maintain her self- possession. She manages it, keeps outwardly calm through scene.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Now -- how does it feel to know you'll have to live with a horror like me the rest of your life?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not very nice. But then there's the compensation of knowing you'll have to live with me the rest of your life. Her attitude makes Holmes progressively sorrier for himse CAMERA MOVES with him as during following he rises, goes stove, pours himself another cup of coffee. He spills a little and the liquid sizzles on the burner.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You don't know how a man feels about a thing like this. It breaks aman all up -- inside.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (dryly) I gander why men feel so differently about it than women.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It's -- it's just not the same. CAMERA MOVES with him as he returns to the table, decides try another tack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think I've done all I have...?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Done all what?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Tried to be a Company Commander when I hate it, worked my fool head off with this miserable boxing squad, tagged after the General whenever I could.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Why, for you and for me. For our home, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (dryly) . I always thought you did it because you wanted to get ahead. She finishes the last of her food, stands.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It's a lovely day out. I think I’l1l go for a walk. Holmes catches her wrist, stops her.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDS
dialogues.text: I’m willing to forgive you. Tell me who he is. Make a clean breast of it. And I'll forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I wonder which is hurt more -- your pride or your curiosity? She disengages her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (coolly) When I'm ready to ask you for a divorce we can discuss it again. She goes to door to pantry, pauses there.  104.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (maternally) And do eat your breakfast, Dana. It's getting cold. She goes out to pantry. We hear the sound of the door to porch opening and closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wretched, completely at a loss. He stares into space, the looks down at his food, picks up a fork and ruefully begi to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew, on hands and knees, is on a weeding detail with thr other men, one of them Sal Anderson. Another is PRIVATE N a tousle-headed, sentimental man we have not seen before. Sergeant Thornhill, in charge of the detail, lolls on the ground, his head propped against a tree, reading a comic book. Prew works his way over to Nair.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You just get out of the Stockade?

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: (nods) It was rugged, sam. But I kept my mouth shut and watched my step and I wasn't in no trouble.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You see Maggio? Nair nods, tells his tale in half-humorous, half-reverent fashion.

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: Fatso’s workin him over with a hoe handle. Places where it won't show mostly. You know, the back and the chest. The kidneys. Once in a while in the face. Know what Maggio does when that happens? Spits in Fatso's eye. (chuckles) Oh, he's a hot one. Ain't he a hot one?  105.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: He's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: Course, he throws up a little blood now and then. And he passes out a lot. But Fatso sure ain't reportin none of that. So there's no way they goin to find out.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Why don't he go to the C.0.?

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: We tried to get him to. But he won't peep. He says he got a lot more scalp to lose first. That boy is about the hardest artery in the hospital. (with great sentiment) But he's got a heart just like a great big baby. Prew's face has been growing in fury. He pulls up a clump sod, throws it down with all his might

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You think he’s gonna be all right?

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: Your guess is worth mine, sam. Maybe he's crackin a little at that -- cause after Fatso put him in the Hole -- that's what they call solitary -- a couple times he began talkin about how he’s gonna e- scape. He said to tell you he’1l look you up one of these nights. A shadow falls across the grass in front of Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING UP from near the ground, the ANGLE EXAGGERATING Galavitch's ungainly, ape-like figure. He lo down at Prew, full of venom.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: Still on knees, eh, Prewitt? Well, boxing finals next month. December f if teen. You s till got time help us make champions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew is at the breaking point. Controlling himself, he we around Galovitch's shadow. It moves in front of Prew agai

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are proud dis Compny to be or not? Bites de hand dat feeds it der shoot dogs for. Infortunately, ony dogs day are allowed to shoot, not men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other men have stopped weeding, are looking over at P and Galovitch. Thornhill, in b.g., puts down the comic bo and comes over to them during following.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Get outa my way, Ike. I ain't gonna move around you again.

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: You need better lesson than up to now. Maybe I give to you myself. Maybe right now. He steps on Prew's hand. As Prew jerks away from the heav shoe Galovitch hauls him up by his fatigue shirt. Thornhi steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: (to Galovitch) Ey, leave him alone. ‘e’s in my detail -- Prew shoves Thornhill aside, cold decision in his eyes. H starts unbuttoning his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (to Galovitch) All right. It's gonna be your way. Galovitch rips off his shirt, bursting some of the button he does. Stripped to the waist, his whole appearance seem change; he looks as he did in the ring, a hard-muscled pr fighter.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: Ey, wait a minute, you guys -- ! Prew is barely able to get out of his shirt before Galovi charges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During following men run from across the quadrangle and f out of the barracks to watch the affair, form a circle ar  107. the fighters. Prew is a skillful boxer, moving around Galovitch quickly and cleverly. Galovitch is more lumberi but not awkward. His heavy blows stagger Prew several tim Prew drives his attack at his opponent's body. He never throws a punch at the other's head.

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: The head, Prew! Hit him in the head! The other men around shout similar advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: puzzled by Prew's concentration on his body and by the sh of the men. He seems to be wondering if Prew is pulling a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fear, not born of cowardice, is reflected on Prew's fac he sets himself, stares at Galovitch. He seems haunted by memory of Dixie Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flinching without being hit. He seems mesmerized by the other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fighting. Galovitch draws blood from a cut over Prew's ey He is getting the better of the battle. In b.g. Thornhill breaks out of the crowd and runs across the quadrangle.

dialogues.speaker: SPECTATOR
dialogues.text: I don't get it -- Why don't Prew go for the head?

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: He blinded a guy once. Must be scairt of the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Galovitch batters Prew back against the crowd. A right the temple sends him to his knees. He shakes his head a moment, gets up and goes into a clinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows are crowded with men watching the fight.  108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT OUT WINDOW To FRONT OF BARRACKS SHOOTING OVER heads of men watching, out to Prew and Galovitch on the ground. Dispassionate, professional ad-l from the men: why does Prew continue his attack to the bo only, a good little man and a good big man, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT WARDEN AND HOLMES FEATURING WARDEN
dialogues.text: Warden is at his desk filling out an application blank. Holmes is glancing over his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden's hand in shot filling out answers to sex, age, ra etc. HOLMES’ VOICE I’1l be glad to recommend you Warden. You've got service, experience, grade. You'll make an excellent officer.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Holmes waits for thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (after hesitating) Thank you, sir. The screen door in the Orderly Room bangs. Thornhill runs into the office, breathless. He comes to a shaking attent as he sees Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: At ease, Sergeant. What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: They fightin on the green, sir! Galovitch and Prewitt.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: Ike looks like ‘e goin to murder him, sir. A pleased look crosses Holmes’ face. Warden jumps up, sta for door. Holmes catches his arm.  109.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: There's no rush. I’1l take care of it. Holmes goes out. Thornhill follows, turns at the door.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: Ain't you want to see it, First?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (shouts suddenly) No! I ain't want to see it! Nor you either! Get out of here! Thornhill goes. The screen door in the Orderly Room bangs Warden walks to his desk, stares down at the application form, picks it up. He carries it over to Holmes' desk. He looks at the picture of Karen on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the picture, then looks at the application blank. Then he looks down at the chevrons on his arm. He his hand over the chevrons gently, fondly. He looks at th application blank again very thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A continuation of the fight. Prew is tiring, his face is and bleeding and there is a welt under one eye. Galovitch unmarked but grunting now from Prew's constant jabs at hi stomach. He seems perplexed, as before, by his opponent+s tactics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURING the non-"ath-a-leets" of G Company, including Anderson, Clark and Treadwell. Ad-libbed shouts of “In th face, Prew! In the face!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURING the "ath-a-loots," including Dhom, Wilson and Henderson. They are watching quietly, nodding with approv as Prew feints, then darts several punches into Galovitch ribs, It almost seems as if they are admiring Prew's cour inwardly rooting for him. Holmes enters the group, Thornh tagging after him. Holmes stops and watches the fight. Th is a look of satisfaction on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fight continuing.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: near rear of crowd. An officer, walking across the lawn, attracted by the noise. He steps into the crowd. This is COLONEL WILLIAMS. He wears the insignia of the Inspector General's Department. He watches the fight, is about to s through to break it up when he sees Holmes. He stops, wat Holmes’ reactions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
