dialogues.text: Prew, backed up against the crowd, trips over somebody's feet. He falls without being hit. Galovitch kicks at him Prew rolls away. The crowd murmurs angrily. Sergeant Star steps out into the open circle, faces Galovitch.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: This ain’t no rassle, Ike. You got to fight this man fair. Approving shouts from the crowd. Stark steps back. Ike wa for Prew to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking up at Galovitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP GALOVITCH’S EYES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes narrow, harden as if his inner struggle has been resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew gets to his feet. As Galovitch comes to him, Prew fe for the stomach, then throws a hard right to Galovitch's face. It hits him flush on the nose. Blood spurts. The cr roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galovitch, surprised and hurt, throws up his hands. Prew drives both fists to his solar plexus. Galovitch drops hi guard. Prew smashes him in the face and Adam's apple. Galovitch falls to his knees, hawking and choking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole nature of the fight has changed. Galovitch, hur and reeling, rushes Prew, bull-like, head down, defense w open. Prew dodges easily, slamming hard with rights and l to the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, seeing Prew is now clearly in command, steps out the crowd and up to the two fighters.  111.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (severely) All right. Let's cut it. There is a look of relief on the faces of both Galovitch Prew as they stop fighting.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What started this?

dialogues.speaker: GALOVITCH
dialogues.text: (puffing) Prewitt talk back to non-com. Refuse order I give him, start fight. I teach him lesson. A laugh from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You won't disobey any more orders in my Company, Prewitt. Warden saved you from a court martial once but he won't this time -- Anderson steps into the circle.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Sir -- I'm sorry, sir but Private Prewitt’s not to blame for this. Sergeant Galovitch started it. Holmes reacts, momentarily at a loss. He turns to Thornhi

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (meaningfully) Thornhill, you're in charge of this detail. How about it? Thornhill steps into the circle, nods toward Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: ‘e’s right, sir. (points to Galovitch) ‘e begun it. Prewitt done nothin. From the crowd step Sergeants Dhom, Wilson and Henderson. They face Holmes and Galovitch implacably.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: No, sir, this wasn't Prewitt's fault.  112.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: That's right, sir. Everybody knows Galovitch started it. Wilson nods. There is a murmur of agreement from the crow Holmes looks at his fighters, rocked by this betrayal. Th stare back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still near the rear of the crowd, he watches the scene wi much interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes pulls himself together, turns to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: That's all. Break it off. Let's get back to our jobs. (to Prew and Galovitch; weakly) I'm giving you two a break. I'll ignore this. He walks off. He does not see Colonel Williams. Galovitch moves off toward the barracks. Wilson, Henderson and Thornhill remain grouped around Prew.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You guys figure this means I'm steppin into a ring, you're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It's your show, kid. Run it the way you want.

dialogues.text: (singing softly) Woke up sick on Thursday Feelin like my head took a dare Looked down at my trousers All my pockets was bare That girl sure was bad news Re-enlistment Blues... The guitars finish the stanza with a flourish as CAMERA H on MEDIUM SHOT. The men chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Some day I’m goin back to Scranton and play it for my folks. And tell em it wan composed in the Hawaiian Islands! Clear across the Pacific Ocean!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (finishes long swig of beer) Hey, Friday.

dialogues.text: Why you called Friday?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Don't know. I was borned on Wednesday. (plucks guitar, sings) Went back around on Friday Asked for a free glass of beer... The three laugh, sing in unison.

CAMERA RETREATS with War as he wanders to the road, still trying to locate the singing. Half-way across the road he unceremoniously sits down, crosses his knees Buddha-wise. dialogues.text: Who goes there?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: A friend.  115.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Advance, friend, and be reconized. Prew moves closer, CAMERA WITH him, until he recognizes Warden.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (roaring, laughing) Quiet! At ease! Fall out! Right dress! ‘bout face! Hit the track! Garbage Detail! Latrine Detail! Dis a drill, not picnic! Hello, kid. Whatever you doin out all by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'm goin to get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Siddown. I got a bottle. He pulls a bottle of whisky from his field jacket, holds up to Prew. Prew takes the bottle and drinks. Then he sit down in the road as matter-of-factly as did Warden. He gi the bottle back to Warden.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I hand it to you, kid. They called off The Treatment this afternoon. When you beat up Ike. I never heard of no soljer before ever lickin The Treatment... (drinks; then holds out bottle) Here, old buddy. Have a lil drink. Prew drinks.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: This is a terrible crummy life, you know it?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Miserble. Perfeckly miserble.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What if a truck or somethin was to come along and run over us?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Awful. Awful. We'd be dead, wouldn't we?  116.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (nods vehemently) An nobody to even mourn. You better not sit here any more. You better get up and move over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What about you? You got more to live for than me. You got to take care of your Compny.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'm old. Don't matter if I die. But your life's ahead of you. You get up.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: No, sir. Never deserted a friend in need. I'll stay to the bitter end.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (shakes head stubbornly) We'll stay together. They square their shoulders heroically.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (as if to an invisible firing squad) No blindfold. Save it to wipe your nose on, you skunk.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Amen. Each takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Prew, I got the biggest troubles in the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: The whole world?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (nods) Take love. Did you personally ever see any of this love? Prew nods gravely.  117.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You'll unerstan, then... This girl see, she wants me to become.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Become what?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (after long hesitation) An officer. Can you see me as an officer?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Sure I can see it. You'd make a good officer.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You both can see more’n I can. You know what, Prew? I'm scared become an officer.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You ain't scared of nothin, Warden.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. I tell myself diffrnt but it's a fack. Where’d I be as an officer? How could I handle him? That's the one thing I'm scared of... be an officer in the U.S. Army. (hastily) Army of the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: A man should be what he can do. Warden nods solemnly as if Prew has uttered a great truth They pass the bottle once more.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: How's your girl? wha'st that name again?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Lorene.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I remember. Lorene. Beautiful name.  118. Warden claps Prew on the shoulder as if he is a lifelong friend. They smile. They look as if they are sharing a gr secret, a secret known to them alone in the world. The mournful guitars and singing comes over a little louder

Warden and look at the car calmly, don't move. The headlights are blazing on them. Stark hops out from the driver's seat, furious.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (assuming anger) Don't you know you got to look out for this man. Get him off the road before you run him over. He's the best stinkin soljer in the Compny.  119.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: You both must be plumb nuts.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: You heard me. Get this man to some safety. Why, he's the best stinkin soljer in the Compny.

dialogues.text: continuing the Taps. There are tears in his eyes now.

It MOVES TOWARD the sign NEW CONGRESS CLUB, HOLDS beside an window through which is heard the sound of harsh piano playing; the pounding style and lack of shading are clear Fatso Judson's. CAMERA PANS AND INCLUDES Prew, leaning against the building. He is watching the entrance to the patiently. There is relentless hatred on his face. The mu stops. Prew does not move.

dialogues.text: Hello, Fatso. Fatso looks around in direction of voice. CAMERA PANS, DISCLOSES Prew, still leaning against the building. Fatso squints, not recognizing him.  125.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: You want me?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yeah, Fatso. Fatso takes a couple of steps toward Prew, squints again.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO
dialogues.text: I don't like that nickname. You want to see me about somethin?

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's step around the corner here where we can talk Prew's voice is so toneless as to be ominous.

dialogues.speaker: FATSO

dialogues.speaker: FATSO

dialogues.text: The American flag, the General's flag and the Division fl are the only colorful elements in a rather severe office. Colonel Williams is reading from a typed report.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: --- In addition to inefficiency in administering his command and neglect of duty, Captain Holmes has been guilty of indefensible cruelty to the aforesaid Private Prewitt. This extended to instigating and encouraging wholly unauthorized and discreditable tactics to force the soldier to join the inter-regiment boxing team. These findings are the result of personal investigation by the Inspector General and are corroborated by numerous members of G Company. Colonel Williams puts his report on the General's desk. Holmes’ face reflects a weary resignation as if underneat has really expected something like this for a long time. makes no move to speak. The General is angry clear throug

dialogues.text: I'm waiting for your reply to this.

dialogues.text: I haven't any, sir... The charges -- are true.

dialogues.text: Holmes, the first thing I ever learned in the Army was that an officer takes care of his men. It seems to be the first thing you forgot. It's monstrous to think of anybody like you in command of troops. And believe me, you won't be for long. My only regret is that we have to keep you in uniform until a court martial is concluded. (MORE )

dialogues.text: GENERAL SLATER(cont'd) In the meantime, of course, I'm relieving you of your present duties. He indicates the meeting is over. Holmes rises, is about leave, pauses.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: If there were any way to avoid a court martial, sir. Any way... The General frowns, is unresponsive. Holmes looks to Colo Williams helplessly.

dialogues.text: There is one alternative, General... if you're so disposed. A resignation for the good of the service under AR 600-275.

dialogues.text: (thinks a moment) I'll give you a chance you don't deserve, Holmes. Write a letter of resignation and have it on my desk this afternoon. I’11 consider accepting it. Only because as far as I'm concerned, the quicker you're out of the Army the better for everybody. Especially the Army.

She shakes her head, not wanting to believe; she takes th letter out of his hand, starts to read it. She stops afte sentence or two. Her hand falls to her side. Holmes sits the bed heavily. dialogues.text: Where has it gone, Karen? What happened to it? The gay, cheerful life we were going to have, you and I...? What happened to me...? The proud, dashing officer was going to be. The leader of men?... I've known all along how the men felt about me. They despised me... What's happened? I don't remember losing anything... Where has it all gone?

dialogues.text: reacting; she is surprised, a little afraid of her own emotion. The outcry, so lost, so despairing, moves her. S is sorry for him.

But a definite respect is reflected in t expressions. Warden, beside his desk, shares this.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: -- I don't intend to have a sloppy outfit. I don't intend to have a goldbrick outfit. I don't intend to have a soft soap outfit. I've called you noncoms in because you're the backbone of any Company. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS(cont 'd) From now on you'll have to prove you're entitled to have those stripes here. And not in the boxing ring. He bands the pictures to Leva.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Get rid of these, Sergeant

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That's all I have to say. If you've any questions, speak up. Nobody speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Dismissed. The men troop out, passing camera. As last man leaves, CA IS ON Warden. He is looking at Ross with considerable approval, even admiration. He resumes a more normal expression as Ross turns toward him.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: One non-com was missing, sir. Sergeant Galovitch.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I know. Private Galovitch is in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: In the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: As of now, he’s an assistant cook. I busted him. On a blanket charge of inefficiency. What are you grinning at?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (grinning) I think the Company Commander made a wise decision, sir. The phone rings. Warden goes to his desk, answers.  133.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Compny G, First Sergeant Warden speaking. Karen's voice is heard on the phone; we cannot understand what she is saying, but a flood of words pours through. W Ross looking on, Warden is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes... Yes, I know... (glances over toward Ross) Yes, the - uh - parcel has already arrived... Yes... What?... (grim now) No. No, we'll have to talk about it soon. Right away. I - I don't know... Ross perceives Warden's distress. He starts toward the do Warden nods gratefully. Ross smiles, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Lissen, I'll get away somehow, tonight. I'll meet you in Kuhio Park. At eight... Right.... He puts down the receiver. He stares at the desk. Then he slowly pulls out the top drawer. The Officers Application Blank is lying on top of a pile of other papers. He takes out, looks at it somberly. CAMERA MOVES IN to an INSERT o the Application. We see Warden's answers to sex, age, rac etc. CAMERA MOVES DOWN the page to the place for the signature of the applicant. It is unsigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. Warden, in uniform, and Karen are sitting on the bench as in their first meeting in the park. We cannot he what they are saying at first. CAMERA MOVES IN past a few pedestrians and HOLDS on a MEDIUM SHOT. There is a defeat tired look about them, as if they have been talking for a long time to no avail.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: : I guess I felt it that night I asked you to become an officer. When you didn't say yes right away. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN(cont 'd) I guess I knew deep down you wouldn't do it. But -- (a hint of tears) It seemed such a simple plan for us...

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I wanted to -- I tried -- but I couldn't... He runs his hand through his hair. He seems to be groping inside himself for some way to explain.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Lissen -- there's a kid in our outfit named Prewitt... Robert E. Lee Prewitt... He came in from the States about a year ago. I thought he was a fresh punk at first... until I got to know him a little. He's AWOL right now -- probly in some kind of real trouble -- he ain't the kind to go AWOL otherwise. Anyway, I keep remembering somethin he said to me the first day he came in. He said a man has got to go his own way... if he don't, he's nothin... I'm an Enlisted Man. I'm a First Sergeant. Milt Warden. Once I cross that line and tried to be an officer, I'm somebody I don't know. A stranger. And a man has got to be what he is...

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I guess that's the trouble with Dana... He's always tried to be something he isn't. Poor Dana... I don't think he ever needed me until now. (shaken herself out of it) Well, here we are saying goodbye. And talking about two other people.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: We're not saying good-bye -- we'll figger out a way for you to stay here --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm going back with him, Milt. There's something in being needed. It isn't love. But it's something.  135.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: (desperately) Lissen, two people who love each other just don't stop loving each other! Nothin and nobody is goin to break us up 1 1111 transfer out somehow and get back to the States. Maybe it'll take a little time but I’1l do it!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (smiles) That sounds like Milt Warden, all right. He bends toward her to kiss her. She presses him back.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: No, Milt. I don't want to kiss you any more. I just want to remember you. And you to remember me.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Put it down. Put it down that on December 6th, 1941, Milton Anthony Warden told you he’d remember you... CAMERA PULLS BACK, PASSES a few pedestrians, Warden and K remaining in b.g. of shot. They begin to talk again, quie undemonstratively. We are too far away now to hear what t are saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma is reading a newspaper in b.g. Prew is disheveled an slovenly, needs a shave badly. His face is lined with pai He is drunk from several days of steady drinking, stone drunk, as if in a trance. He wears crumpled civilian clot He is at a table laboriously writing out the Re-enlistmen Blues. He finishes writing a stanza and sings softly.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Slep in the park that Sunday Seen all the folks gain to church Your belly feel so empty When you're left in the lurch -- Alma looks up from the paper.  136.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Here it is -- they're putting it on an inside page already. (reads) ‘,.. Still no clue in the fatal stabbing of Staff Sergeant James R. Judson...’ Prew, who has stopped singing but not turned his head, resumes the song.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Dog soljers don't own pews Re-enlistment Blues...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Did you hear me? Are you listening or not? Prew nods blankly. He rises slowly and walks across the r toward Alma. But his eyes are fixed on a whisky bottle on table beside her. He moves stiffly, favoring his side, hi face contorted. He picks up the bottle, pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (coldly) Are you trying to set a new world’s record?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles faintly, holds the glass high.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Yeah... To the memory of Robert E. Lee Prewitt, Holder of the New World's Record...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I want to know what you plan to do.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Plan to do? when?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Any time. Now. Tomorrow. Next week.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Lessee... (counts on fingers) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREW(cont 'd) ... One... two... three... four... Four days I'm AWOL, ain't I? (picks up paper, looks at date) ... this is December sixth, ain't it...?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (half-tirade, half -wail) It's December sixth and you're so drunk you're wall-eyed. And all you've done since you fell in here is drink and drink and drink and try to remember that old song of yours. And I want to know what you're going to do! Prew looks at her, hurt. He moves back to his table, mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: . might ship out on a tramp and go to Mexico and be a cowboy...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Oh, be sensible! Prew sits at the table again, continues to mumble.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'm goin back to the Compny... soon's my side heals... Goin back under my own power... Goin into the Ordrly Room 'n' say hello, Warden, Private Prewitt reportin...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (breaking) Oh, Prew! Prew! Why did you have to do it? why did you have to kill that man? Prew shakes his head sadly as if he doesn't know the answ He picks up the paper he has been writing on, sings softl testing the last couple of lines affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Recruitin crews give me the blues Old Re-enlistment Blues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FEATURES clock on wall reading 7:52. About half th Company is at breakfast. There is considerable laughter a horseplay. Near the kitchen a dozen men are in the chow l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURING Warden at the NCO table. He rises, carries his plate with him towards the chow line. A sudden, deep-tone earthquake-like blast shudders through the room. The cups the tables rattle. Warden stops, cocks his head. The men eating, look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (to the room) Must be dynamitin down to Wheeler Field.

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: Them engineers mighty ambitious Sunday mornin before eight o'clock The men resume eating. Warden moves a couple of steps tow the chow line when the second blast hits. It is much heav and fuller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a hunch about this now. He reaches out to put his plate down, holding it very carefully in both hands. Howe he doesn't bother to see if there is anything under it. T plate falls and crashes on the floor a fraction of a seco before the third groundswell of blast shakes the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sprints toward the mess hall, yelling to right and at the top of his lungs. As he approaches camera we see i Mazzioli.

dialogues.speaker: MAZZIOLI
dialogues.text: The Japs’re bombing Wheeler Field! It's the Japs! They're bombing Wheeler Field! The Japs! It's the Japs! I saw the red circles on the wings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roar of the plane over shot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure of Mazzioli gets closer and closer as the plan  139. dives toward him, machine guns spitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Jap plane flashes by close above him. The stones i the pavement pop up. Mazzioli flops on the street. The pl zooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men rush out. In the front ranks are Warden, Karel Stark and Choate, Choate carries his half-filled plate in hand, a mug of coffee in the other. The men stretch their necks, following the plane. Then they look back up the street, CAMERA PANNING. Far in b.g, a column of black mushrooming to the sky. Warden dashes to Mazzioli. CAMERA MOVES IN to a CLOSE SHOT as Warden bends over him, hoists to a sitting position. He is extremely gentle. Mazzioli's knee is laid open and is bleeding freely. Warden whips ou handkerchief and starts to apply a tourniquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the men continue to crane at the sky. A few pick metal links from the Jap bullets.

dialogues.speaker: NAIR
dialogues.text: Say! This’1l1 make me a good souvenir! A bullet from a Jap plane!

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: This ain't jawbone! This is for record. Theme real bullets that guy was uSin. Get inside -- all of ya! Warden gets Mazzioli to his feet, turns to first man in g surrounding them. It is Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Help him over to the hospital. Anderson starts Mazzioli down the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of planes are diving toward the street WARDEN’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men rush for cover, all except Choate who is left alo in shot. He takes a big bite of his sausage and eggs, has downs a swig of coffee. Then he throws the plate and cup the street and dives for cover as the terrifyingly loud n of the Jap planes indicates they are directly overhead.  140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are pouring in from the Company street, all shout at once. Warden pushes his way through them and jumps up the pool table. His big voice booms.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: All right, all right, you men! Quiet down! Quiet down! It's only a war. Ain't you ever been in a war before? The men begin to quiet down, look to Warden respectfully. Through the scene the heavy earth shudders are felt and h as bombs hit in the far distance. Also the sound of the strafing planes.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: We're gonna organize a fire umbrella defense. I want the non- coms to get BARs and ammunition from the Supply Room and get up on the roof. Henderson, you're in charge of the loading detail. Get movin! The non-coms push out the door.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: Hey, what about me? I been waitin all my life to git to shoot a BAR at somethin!

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Okay. It's your life. Treadwell hurries after the non-coms.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: The rest of you guys - the CQ will unlock the rifle racks. Every man get his rifle and go to his bunk and stay there. And I mean stay there! I'm making each squad leader responsible to keep his men inside. If you have to use a rifle butt to do it, that's okay, too. There are shouts of protest. The men are over the first s now and beginning to get angry, anxious for action.  141.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You heard me! This ain't no Maneuvers. You go runnin around outside you'll get your ears shot off. You want to be heroes, you'll get plenty chances later. You'll probly have Japs in your laps before night.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: What if they bomb us?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You hear a bomb comin, you're free to take off for the brush. But don't worry -- the Japs’1l probly drop all their bombs on Pearl Harbor and Hickam. They ain't gonna waste ‘em on us. So let's can the chatter. We're wastin time. Squad leaders, get ‘em upstairs! Squad leaders begin to herd their men out. Warden jumps o the pool table. Stark and Karelsen come up to him.

dialogues.speaker: STARK
dialogues.text: What you want me to do, First? I got a hangover, but I can still --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You stick in the kitchen and make a big pot of coffee. No -- make a barrel of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: I think I could get one of them Japs with a machine gun, Milt. We'll put the tripod over a chimney. And hold her down by the legs.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Pete. They smile at each other affectionately, then push into t crowd leaving the Day Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The non-coma are arguing violently with Leva at the door the Supply Room. Jap planes are loud overhead.  142.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: I don't care. I can't issue any live ammunition without a signed order from an officer.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: But there ain't no officers yet, you jerk! Lieutenant Ross lives off the post.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: (folds arms) I'm sorry fellows. Lieutenant Ross give me them orders himself. No signed order, no ammo. And that's all they are to it. Warden hurries up to the group.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: He won't let us have no ammo, Top!

dialogues.speaker: CHOATE
dialogues.text: Hats got it locked up. An the keys in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Gimme them keys!

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: I can't, Top. I got to obey my orders. No live ammo without a signed -- They flatten against the wall as a Jap plane roars buildi high down the street, machine guns flaring. After it pass they rush back to Lava,

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You blind? You see them planes --?! Lava puts his hand in his pocket protectively, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: I ain’t gonna do it, Top. I --

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Chief, bust the door down. (to Leva) Get the hell out of the way!  143. Choate, Henderson and Dhom back up for a run at the door. Leva moves in front of the door

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Bust it down. He'll get out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: LEVA
dialogues.text: Remember I warned you. I did my best.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll see you get a medal. Warden dashes up the porch steps as Choate, Henderson and Dhom launch themselves at the door. Leva steps aside. The door rattles ponderously, then flies open. The three battering rams careen into the Supply Room. The men stand by cheer and rush in after them. Leva shakes his head gri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are sitting on their bunks, unhappily, holding th rifles. Others who have slept through breakfast are dress hastily. Warden rushes into the room. The men immediately bark ad-libbed questions at him:

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: (ad lib) What's the deal, First? Why can't we go up on the roof? Where's the ammo, Top? Are we soljers -- or Boy Scouts?

dialogues.speaker: WARN
dialogues.text: (pitilessly) Start rollin full field packs! We may have to move out of here. Squad leaders, get ‘em packin! In b.g. Henderson and others are going up the porch stair the roof. They tote BARs and loading clips. Karelsen and helpers follow with a heavy machine gun and belt boxes. Warden starts for the porch stairs. He is attracted by something, stops, looks out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lying under an empty bunk with three mattresses piled on He is in his underwear and a helmet, hugs his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You'll catch a cold, Turp.

dialogues.speaker: THORNHILL
dialogues.text: Don't go out there, First Sergeant! You'll be killed! They're shootin it up! You'll be dead! You'll not be alive any more. Don't go out there!

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You better put your pants on. Warden hits the floor as a plane is heard so loud and low sounds as if it's coming right into the room. A dotted li of bullets crosses the floor and moves into Warden's and Karelsen's room. Warden jumps up and rushes into the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden runs in. Broken glass lies all over the floor. Bullet holes are stitched across the top of Warden's footlocker. He throws back the lid fiercely. His linen is polka-dotted with holes. He tosses out shirts, shorts, et digs underneath them. He pulls out a quart bottle of whis it is untouched. Warden smiles with relief. He lifts the bottle to his lips, drinks long and heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty of Company GIs men, including almost all the cams, are on the roof, They are crouched behind the chimn or down on their knees in the corners. The BARs are propp on the low walls or chimney tops, their muzzles pointed t the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Jap planes, forming a V, are heading straight for camera.

dialogues.speaker: DHOM
dialogues.text: (shouting) Come on, you dirty sons -- The scream of the planes drowns Dhom’s voice. There is a tremendous clatter as the men fire. The Jap planes pass, untouched.  145. From this moment on there is no letup of the noise -- the is a wild cacophony of Jap planes, BARs, Karelsen’s machi gun, the deep sound of bombs hitting in the far distance. Chief Choate, singing the Regimental marching song, loudl and lustily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden comes up on the roof through the skylight. He shouts incoherently at the men. They shout back in a wild cheer. They are like a pack of hungry men enjoying their first big meal in years. In b.g. the Jap V has swung abou and heads back. Warden grabs a BAR from the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grinning as his plane dives, its guns roaring. His silk s ripples out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing the BAR, standing, as the Jap planes roar over. He staggers back from the recoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men fire in unison. They rise after the planes pass, shake their fists. Henderson and others of the loading de appear on the roof, bringing up more ammunition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets out a hoarse yell of glee and pride. "These are m boys. This is my Company," it seems to say. The men answe back with a great answering shout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden makes a tour of the roof, laughing, exhorting, slapping the men on their buttocks like a quarterback. Th respond with tremendous spirit; they are having one hell time. We get only a snatch of what Warden is yelling.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: -- Don't worry about wasting ammo! Throw your empty clips down into the yard. The loading detail will pick ‘em up -- The sound of a bugle blowing insistently is now heard, blending into the rest of the noise. Treadwell runs to th edge of the roof, looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Bugler's post, Friday Clark is sounding a call.

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: Treadwell turns, yells at the men.  146.

dialogues.speaker: TREADWELL
dialogues.text: Friday's gone crazy! He's blowing the Cavalry Charge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cheeks puffed, blowing the bugle madly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is lying on a couch in pajamas. He has not shaven, his hair is unkempt. A Radio Announcer is heard over shot. Pr wakens, groggy with hangover and near-delirium, wrestles the blanket over him. CAMERA PULLS BACK to MEDIUM SHOT, DISCLOSING Alma and Gorgette. They have negligees over th nightgowns, are listening to the radio. The Announcer's v tries hard to be calm and official but he cannot keep the tremor out of it. (NOTE: Transcripts of the actual broadc have been requested. )

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: This is a real attack, not a Maneuver. The Japanese are bombing Pearl Harbor. Please keep in your homes. Do not go on the streets. I repeat, this is a real attack. Japanese planes are bombing our naval and army installations. Civilians will remain in their homes. This is a real attack - The Announcer's voice goes on as above.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (mutters) Oh, those dirty Germans... Those dirty sneakin Germans...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: What Germans?!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (points to the radio) Them...

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: It's the Japs. The Japs!  147.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: . Attacks are now taking place at Pearl, Wheeler, Hickam and Schofield...

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: dirty Germans... Alma shakes Prew, hard. He falls back on the couch, passe out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jap strafing attack is continuing. Their planes are making a figure 8 in the sky. Silhouettes of men on the r can b e seen. Friday Clark is blowing his Cavalry Charge. b.g. men of the loading detail are scurrying around. Lieutenant Ross runs into shot. CAMERA PANS him across th quadrangle toward the barracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Ross is hailed by the loading detail -- about men. He grabs a BAR and ammunition from them and runs int the barracks. The loading detail is working feverishly, s carrying ammunition into the barracks, others picking up empty clips as they are thrown from the roof and hustling them toward the Supply Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is working hard, passing out ammunition to members of loading detail. But he shakes his head dourly as if the w thing is still very unofficial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, pandemonium -- but controlled and efficient. T men are hoarse from shouting, red-eyed, puffing from excitement and exertion. Two Jap planes swoop past and th full-throated umbrella of fire lets loose. Lieutenant Ros clambers onto the roof, stooping under the burden of the and loading clips. The men greet him with a concerted che TwO SHOT LIEUTENANT ROSS AND WARDEN Ross looks around the roof, nods with evident approval, c Warden on the shoulder. DHOM’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of Jap planes comes up ear-splitting loud. Ross dro down behind a chimney, swings his BAR, fires. CAMERA MOVE INCLUDE Karelsen at the other side of the chimney, firing machine gun. Two soldiers hang onto the bucking legs of t tripod. Two Jap planes pass in b.g. of shot, zoom off int the sky.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Nuts! Led him too tar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men on the roof reload. In the distance the Jap pl have turned and are heading back for the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their lips curled bitterly as their planes head for the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing a BAR at the planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing Joyously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: singing as he fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing the machine gun. He yanks the tripod away from his helpers, picks up the gun, stands and swings it after the plane. The recoil staggers him half way across the roof a deposits him on his rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps in his seat like a man tied to a hot stove, thro up his arms helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jap plane bursts into flame and crashes.

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: The men rise as one with an uproarious cheer. They rush t Karelsen, pick him up. Warden lets go with another of his rebel yells.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You got him, Pete! You got him!  149.

dialogues.speaker: KARELSEN
dialogues.text: (spits over roof) Ah, nobody’11 ever know which of us got that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men return to their positions. Two planes head for them, pass over as Company G lets go again with everythin has.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (pointing after second of the planes) Hey! That last one was one of ours! That was an American plane!

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Well, he ain't got no business here. We're takin care of this sector!

dialogues.speaker: SHOT SHOOTING FROM ROOF JAP PLANE
dialogues.text: swooping across the quadrangle about ten feet from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday Clark, blowing the Cavalry Charge madly, abandons megaphone as he sees the plane coming. He drops on his ch hugging the bugle. The plane passes. Clark jumps up instantly, resumes blowing the Charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same plane has gained altitude so that it is a few fe above the barracks as it heads straight for the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men flatten, all but Warden. He stands, swings his BA toward the plane. CAMERA IS ANGLED so that Warden is silhouetted against the sky as he fires at the Jap plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It misses the roof by a foot or two, zooms up at a weird angle. A thick cloud of smoke pours out of the engine. Th plane falls off on one wing and crashes into trees at the of the quadrangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crashing. The gas-tank explodes. A cloud of fire and blac  150. smoke obscures the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are improvised blackout curtains over windows and t glass doors. The radio is on, volume low, and an announce (not the one of the morning) is droning out an account of Pearl Harbor. Prew, still on the couch in his pajamas, lo as if he has just struggled to wakefulness. He listens to radio for a few moments in confused disbelief. He shakes head vigorously as if to throw off his grogginess. He sha his head again, slowly, more knowingly now, nodding as if remembers something from the broadcast of the morning. Th as if all of it hits him suddenly and fully and terribly wrenches himself off the couch. He looks around at the di lit room.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Alma! Alma! He goes to the blackout curtains, peeps out. Then he turn back to listen to the radio. Abruptly, he runs into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Alma! The room remains empty for a few moments as the radio announcer goes on, continuing previous remarks.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- ready to fight and die for us our Regular Army and Navy have this day upheld the faith and confidence we have always placed in them. They have proved their right to the esteem we have always had for them... Prew comes back into the room. He has his shoes on, holds civilian shirt and pants in his hand. He starts to put th on hurriedly, his attention still focused on the broadcas The front door opens and Alma and Gorgette enter. They ar surprised to see Prew up. He nods at them, turns back qui to listen to the radio as he continues dressing.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: the attack caused serious damage to many installations of which Pearl Harbor suffered the worst. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE(cont'd) We will not forget this day -- and we will never let the Japanese forget it...

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: (yells at radio) You said it! who they think they're fight in? (incoherent with rage; to girls) They're pickin trouble with the best Army in -- the best riflemen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you know we the ony country on the face of the earth that uses the shooting gunsling, not the carrying gunsling. You know that? The radio continues on under the scene. Alma and Gorgette speak breathlessly, in a rush.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: We've been at Queens Hospital -- giving blood --

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: The town's a madhouse. Trucks busses, jeeps all over --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: A house on Kuhio Street was bombed out --

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: And the drugstore on McKully and King is smashed flat. And the man and his wife were killed -- Prew gestures to radio as if he's heard all about it. He sticks his shirttails into his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I gotta get back to the Post -- I'll try to get in touch with you in a couple days --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: The Post? Tonight? Prew nods vehemently, moves across room to a table.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: But why?  152.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Why? There's a war goin on.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: But you can't! You're not fit yet -- you're weak as a kitten -- you're AWOL -- they'll throw you in the Stockade -- PREP. (laughs wildly) They’11 be throwin ‘em out of the Stockade. They need every man they can get. He picks up the sheet of paper with the "Re-enlistment Bl written out on it, starts to fold it. Desperation is reflected on Alma's face; she turns to Gorgette, as if pleading for aid,

dialogues.speaker: GORGETTE
dialogues.text: Your side’1l open up --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: And they'll find out it was you who killed that soldier! Prew shakes his head, as if obsessed by only one thought.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Once I report in to the Compny I'll be all right. Once I get there. I gotta get back --

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: But you'll never make it! There's MPs all over --

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: I'll make it. I'll go along the back roads. They'll let me in the West gate -- they'll know I'ma soljer -- He puts the folded piece of paper in his pocket and start for the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Stay till morning! Prew glances at Alma incredulously. She sobs suddenly, violently.  153.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Maybe if you stayed till morning you'd change your mind... She throws her arms around him, clings to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Don't go, Prew! I'll do whatever you want... We'll figure out a way to get to the States together... We can even get married... If you go I won't see you any more... I know it... Prew holds her closely for a moment, then moves her away him. He turns toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (tears turning to hysteria) What do you want to go back to the Army for?! What did the Army ever do for you? Besides treat you like scum and give you one awful going over and get your friend killed? What do you want to go back to that for? Prew frowns as if he's not sure he heard correctly.

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: What do I want to go back for? I'm a soljer.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (laughing wildly) A soldier! A soldier! A Regular. From the Regular Army. A thirty- year man!

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: Sure. A thirty-year man. (grins) With only twenty-six years to go. He opens the door quickly and slips into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY ADJOINING GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT JEEP WITH THREE MPs The night is inky black except for a little moonlight and  154. dimmed headlights of the jeep. CAMERA SHOOTS PAST driver the highway as the jeep moves slowly along. The two other clutch Thompson guns, try to scan the dark countryside.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MP
dialogues.text: They say they seen parachutists land up in the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MP
dialogues.text: I ain’t worried about them. Sabatoors is what worries me.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Theys the creepy ones. Walkin around just like ordinary civilians. I betcha they operatin all over these islands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlights pass along the road as the jeep moves on o of sight. As its sound fades we hear Prew's heavy breathi are barely able to distinguish his figure in the darkness is crouched, watching the car go down the highway. We hea his thoughts. The voice is labored and agonized.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: almost home... ony across the golf course... now... now... no... wait... gotta be care?... gotta sweat it out... He groans, puts his hand to his side. In the feeble light from the moon we see blood on his shirt and hand. He look and down the road. PREW’S VOICE (0.S.) it's clear now... gotta get home... Still crouched, Prew starts across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see nothing but the strip of road, then Prewts figure visible, bent low, weaving a little. As he approaches the camera, he is taught square in the twin beams of dimmed headlights which flash on from the side of the road. Now see that a jeep is parked near camera, heading in the opposite direction from the jeep which passed before. It also manned by three MPs. There is a startled cry from Pr MP’S VOICE Halt!  155. Prew starts to run back across the road. A white spotligh flashes on, its harsh brilliant light following him. Prew slips to one knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking toward the jeep, blinded by the blazing light. He the appearance of a terrified animal. There is a wildness senselessness about him. The blotch of blood oozes and spreads over his shirt. He picks up a rock from the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew rises, staggers away from the jeep. MP’S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: HALT
dialogues.text: Prew flings the rock desperately toward the lights. There a crash of glass and one headlight winks off. Prew runs across the road and onto the golf course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motor starts, The jeep moves out from its hiding plac and starts across the golf course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew, in a skirmisher's zigzag, is trying to elude the spotlight. He is about twenty yards in front of the jeep. heads for a high sandtrap. The spot is full on him as he reaches the lip of the trap. He turns, yells something ba at the jeep. It is barely heard over the sound of the jee

dialogues.speaker: PREW
dialogues.text: -- I'ma soljer! --

dialogues.speaker: MP
dialogues.text: That guy ain’t no soljer -- he dint halt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing on the lip of the trap, the jeep bearing down on him. He turns, starts to dive into the trap. A blast of gunfire from the jeep hits him. He falls sideways into th trap, rolls over on his back, The jeep moves into the sho crawls half-way over the trap, stops, its spotlight pouri down on Prew. His eyes are open, looking up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS DOWN to Prew from top of trap. A portion of jeep is in shot, but we are not able to see the MPs.

dialogues.speaker: MP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (quavering, almost tearful) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MP'S VOICE(cont'd) -- maybe he was a soljer -- I dint mean to kill him -- I dint mean it, guys -- you know we got orders --

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Shut up. The voices are lost as CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY DOWN toward Pr open eyes. We hear his thoughts on the sound track, clear fast at first and slow and almost inaudible as the CAMERA REACHES A FULL HEAD CLOSEUP.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE
dialogues.text: sweat it out and sweat it out and wait and wait and wait for it... and now it's here... it's here... gotta see to do it well... gotta do it well... won't take long... CAMERA MOVES CLOSER TO CLOSEUP of Prew's open eyes. PREW’S VOICE just a little more now... gotta do it good... it'll be over... nobody lies... lonely... a man has... got to have some place... Prew's eyes close. THE SCREEN GOES BLACK. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK LEADER
dialogues.text: There is no sound as the screen remains black for several beats.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: TwO SHOT WARDEN AND A LIEUTENANT COLONEL They are looking down to camera, which SHOOTS UP as if fr point of view of Prew's body in the sand trap. The dimmed headlights of two jeeps illuminates them. Warden is fight to control his emotion, to remain the professional soldie The Lieutenant Colonel is disturbed, but kindly.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: Where's your Company Commander?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: He's at Headquarters, sir. I'm the First Sergeant.  157.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: Did you know this man personally?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are standing on the lip of the sandtrap. The hoods o the jeeps that chased Prew and the second jeep are just behind them in shot.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: He didn't have any regular identification. But they found a card on him with his name -- (holds card close to headlight) -- seems to be a membership in a club. The -- New Congress Club.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The Lieutenant Colonel hands the card to Warden.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: I'll turn this over to you. And these other things that were on him. This -- He unfolds a sheet of paper, holds it to the headlight. H and Warden squint at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Re-enlistment Blues" is written at the top. The stanzas the song are beneath the heading.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Seems to be acme sort of poem.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, air. Very softly, so distant that we can only distinguish a wo or two now and then, we hear the voices of Clark, Anderso and Prew singing the "Re-enlistment Blues." The plaintive melody continues under the rest of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: And this. Whatever it is.  158. He holds Prew' s bugle mouthpiece up to the light, gives to Warden. Warden holds it in his hand, stares at it. Und the "Re-enlistment Blues," even softer, farther away, we hear Prew's bugle blowing Taps. It continues, with the so to the end of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: It’s the mouthpiece of a bugle. The Lieutenant Colonel looks at Warden closely.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Sergeant? Was this man a friend of yours? Warden speaks very formally.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Sir, this man was a good soldier. He loved the Army moren any soljer I ever knew. I would like to make a formal request that this body be buried in the Army's permanent cemetery at Schofield Barracks.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: I believe I can attend to that for you.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sergeant. The Lieutenant Colonel walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INCLUDING Prew's body in the shot as Warden looks down at He looks at it for several moments. The Taps is just comi to an end. Warden speaks very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: No, sir. I hardly knew the guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taps and the Re-enlistment Blues are swept away by the lu strains of Aloha Oe. The Hawaiian music continues through scene.  159.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking back at the city. Around her neck is a gar of leis.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's very beautiful, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and CAMERA PANS to INCLUDE Alma in shot, standi beside Karen. She is dressed in black, quite severely.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (sociably) I think It's the most beautiful place I ever saw in my lire.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: No one would know there was a war from out here. Karen takes off her leis, begins tossing them over the ra

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: There's a legend. If they float in toward shore, you'll come back some day. If they float out to sea, you won't.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: I won't come back. I had to get away from here. You see, my fiance was killed on December seventh.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh, I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: (quickly, as if rehearsed) He was a bomber pilot. He tried to taxi his plane off the apron and the Japs made a direct hit on it. Maybe you read about it in the papers. They awarded him a Silver Star. They sent it to his mother. She wrote me she wanted me to have it.  160.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (tossing the last of leis over ) That's very fine of her.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: They’re very fine people. Southern people. He was named after a General. Robert E. Lee -- Prewitt. Karen looks at Alma numbly. Alma is looking out across th water.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Robert E. Lee Prewitt. (on verge of tears) Isn't that a silly old name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are floating on the water behind the ship. They are being carried out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A choppy wave washes over it, submerges it. FADE OUT.
